{{infobox person |name = Jeannie Saffin |birth_name = Jeanne Lucille Saffin |birth_date = {{birth date|1921|3|20}} |birth_place = [[Edmonton, London]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|1982|9|23|1921|3|20}} |death_place = [[Northwood, London]], England |known = Odd circumstances surrounding death |death_cause = Spontaneous human combustion (presumably) }} '''Jeanne Lucille Saffin''' (20 March 1921<ref>''England & Wales, Civil Registration Death Index, 1916-2007''</ref> – 23 September 1982) was a British woman whose death from fire in 1982 is cited by [[paranormal]] researchers and authors as an example of [[spontaneous human combustion]], and is reported to be the most recent suspected case in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/spontaneous-combustion-killed-pensioner-rules-coroner-2360082.html|title=Spontaneous combustion killed pensioner, rules coroner|last=Blake|first=Matt|date=24 September 2011|work=The Independent|accessdate=7 January 2012}}</ref> Aspects of the reports made immediately after her injury and death apparently supported the conclusion that her death was due to spontaneous human combustion; John Heymer devoted a chapter of his 1996 book ''[[The Entrancing Flame]]'' to the case.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nickell|first=Joe|date=March–April 1998|title=Fiery Tales That Spontaneously Destruct|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|publisher=The Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|volume=22.2|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/fiery_tales_that_spontaneously_destruct/}}</ref> However, later research has cast doubt on some of the evidence and refutes the claims that her injuries were caused by spontaneous human combustion.
==Death== Jeannie Saffin was born in [[Edmonton, London]]<ref>''England & Wales, Birth Index: 1916-2005''</ref> with birth defects that led to mental handicaps which reduced her abilities to those of a child. She was 61 years old at the time of her death. On the evening of 15 September 1982, she was at the family's home in Edmonton with her father, Jack Saffin, and her brother-in-law, Don Carroll. Jeannie was sitting with her father in the kitchen. Jack Saffin was looking away from Jeannie when his attention was drawn to his daughter as she was suddenly on fire. Jack Saffin and his son-in-law Don Carroll put out the fire using water from the kitchen, and then called for an ambulance. Jeannie was treated en route to the hospital by paramedics, admitted to [[North Middlesex Hospital]], and then transferred to the burn unit at [[Mount Vernon Hospital]], where she was treated until her death caused by "[[pneumonia|broncho-pneumonia]] due to burns" eight days after the original fire and injury.<ref name="xfiles">{{cite book | title=Real-life X-Files | publisher=The University Press of Kentucky | author=Nickell, Joe | year=2001 | location=Lexington, KY | pages=240–245 | isbn=0-8131-2210-4}}</ref> Relatives suggested at the inquest that the death could have been a case of spontaneous human combustion, but the coroner, Dr John Burton, said there was "no such thing" and gave an open verdict.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/4456428.stm|title=Does spontaneous human combustion exist?|date=21 November 2005|work=BBC News Magazine|accessdate=7 January 2012}}</ref>
==Spontaneous human combustion== Saffin's case has been held as an example of spontaneous human combustion by paranormal researchers and authors. Jack Saffin's son-in-law, Don Carroll, who was in the home at the time of the fire, has stated that Jeannie had flames coming from her mouth, and made roaring noises like a [[dragon]].<ref name="Heymer">{{cite book | title=[[The Entrancing Flame]]: The Facts of Spontaneous Human Combustion | publisher=Little, Brown | author=Heymer, John E. | year=1996 | location=London}}</ref> Both Carroll and Jack Saffin have repeatedly claimed that prior to Jeannie being lit aflame there was no source of ignition in the kitchen except the [[pilot light]] on the gas stove.<ref name="Heymer" /> Carroll also states that Jeannie's clothes were unburned and that there was no smoke damage in the kitchen.<ref name="Arnold">{{cite book | title=Ablaze! The Mysterious Fires of Spontaneous Human Combustion | publisher=M. Evans & Co. | author=Arnold, Larry E. | year=1995 | location=New York}}</ref> The interpretation of Heymer and Arnold's works have led to Saffi'’s case as being quoted as proof of spontaneous human combustion by researchers and authors anxious to make the case for spontaneous human combustion.<ref name="Lake">{{cite book | title=Weird England | publisher=Sterling Publishing| author=Lake, Matt | year=2007 | location=New York | page=81 | isbn=978-1-4027-4229-3}}</ref>
An alternate view debunks the evidence pointing towards Saffin being an example of spontaneous human combustion. Proponents of the combustion theory have stated that Saffin "came to be burned inside unburned clothes,"<ref>Heymer, ''The Entrancing Flame'', p. 187.</ref> However, later research noted by [[Joe Nickell]] suggests that Saffin's clothes were burned. In a written statement given at the time of Saffin's death, 12 years before the interview conducted by Heymer, Carroll stated that Saffin's clothes were severely burned.<ref name="xfiles" /> Also, police reports indicated that upon their arrival, [[constable]]s witnessed Jeannie's clothing burning and removed it after putting out the flames.<ref name="xfiles" />
The source of the flames has also been scrutinized by skeptics. Carroll has stated that the flames came from Saffin's mouth; however, the medical evidence does not support this conclusion: Saffin's mouth was undamaged, according to hospital records.<ref name="xfiles" /> Medical records also support the conclusion that the majority of Saffin's burns were the result of contact with burning or melted [[nylon]] from her clothing. The burning and melting patterns of her nylon clothing could make it appear that the fire was coming from inside Saffin's body.<ref name="xfiles" />
Opponents of the spontaneous human combustion theory also have a potential explanation for the source of the flame that ignited Saffin's clothing, causing the fire. Carroll made several statements that the only source of flame in the kitchen was the pilot light for the stove. In one interview he specifically noted that Jack Saffin's [[Smoking pipe (tobacco)|pipe]] was unlit and filled with fresh tobacco.<ref name="xfiles" /> Nickell outlines a plausible explanation, that Jack Saffin knocked out used tobacco from his pipe in order to refill it, and that while doing so, caused lit embers of pipe tobacco to land on Jeannie's clothing. Nickell suggests this is even more likely, because at the time of the fire, the kitchen window and door were open, causing a cross breeze.<ref name="xfiles" /> Pipe embers, carried by the breeze and then landing on Saffin's flammable nylon clothing, would easily catch fire and cause the severe burns found on Saffin's body at autopsy.<ref name="xfiles" />
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Saffin, Jeannie}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from fire]] [[Category:Deaths by person]] [[Category:Death in London]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in England]] [[Category:Paranormal]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]]

{{Orphan|date=September 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox video game series | title = Dysfunctional Systems | image = Dischan Media - Dysfunctional Systems TC.jpg | caption = Series title card | genre = [[Visual novel]] | developer = Dischan Media | publisher = Dischan Media | creator = | artist = Saimon Ma (for Episode 1) | writer = Terrence Smith | composer = Kristian Jensen | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Linux]], [[iOS]]{{cite web|url=https://dischan.org/devblog/2013/07/leaked-dysfunctional-systems-for-ios/ |title=**LEAKED** Dysfunctional Systems for iOS | Devblog |publisher=Dischan.org |date=2013-07-21 |accessdate=2014-03-18}} | platform of origin = Microsoft Windows, macOS, Linux | year of inception = 2012 | first release version = ''Episode 1'' | first release date = April 4, 2013 | spinoffs = }} '''''Dysfunctional Systems''''' is a [[visual novel]] created by Canadian studio Dischan Media. The story follows Winter Harrison, a "mediator"-in-training, as she attempts to resolve chaotic situations in different worlds. The first of several planned episodes, ''Learning to Manage Chaos'', was released on April 4, 2013{{cite web|title=Dysfunctional Systems|url=http://www.dysfunctionalsystems.com/|publisher=Dischan Media|accessdate=January 23, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://indiestatik.com/2013/01/06/dysfunctional-systems-explores-real-political-issues-through-sci-fi-visual-novel-form/|title=Dysfunctional Systems Explores Real Political Issues Through Sci-Fi Visual Novel Form|last=Priestman|first=Chris|authorlink=|date=January 6, 2013|work=Indie Statik|publisher=|accessdate=January 28, 2013}}{{cite web|author=Smith, Terrence|url=http://dischan.org/devblog/2013/04/dysfunctional-systems-learning-to-manage-chaos-released/|title="Dysfunctional Systems: Learning to Manage Chaos" Released | Devblog|publisher=Dischan.org|date=|accessdate=April 7, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408091838/http://dischan.org/devblog/2013/04/dysfunctional-systems-learning-to-manage-chaos-released/|archivedate=April 8, 2013|df=mdy-all}} In February 2014, Dischan launched a [[Kickstarter]] campaign to raise funds for another two episodes of the story.{{cite web|title=Dischan State of Affairs |url=https://dischan.org/devblog/2014/01/dischan-state-of-affairs/ |publisher=Dischan Media |accessdate=January 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111040128/https://dischan.org/devblog/2014/01/dischan-state-of-affairs/ |archivedate=January 11, 2014 |df=mdy }}{{cite web |url=http://rpgfan.com/news/2014/1236.html |title=Visual Novel Series Dysfunctional Systems Gets Kickstarted |last=Barker |first=Andrew |publisher=RPGFan |date=2014-03-01 |accessdate=2014-03-03}} Although the campaign met and exceeded its funding goals, the project was cancelled on January 2, 2015.{{cite web|title=Kickstarter Episode 2 Cancellation|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dischan/dysfunctional-systems/posts/1098187|website=www.kickstarter.com|accessdate=2015-01-02}} The series was restarted with the release of a prequel episode, ''Dysfunctional Systems: Orientation'' on July 24, 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/337890/Dysfunctional_Systems_Orientation/|title=Save 10% on Dysfunctional Systems: Orientation on Steam|website=store.steampowered.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-28}} ==Gameplay== [[File:Dischan Media - Dysfunctional Systems Ep1 Gameplay.jpg|thumb|left|270px|Gameplay from ''Episode 1''. Here, Cyrus (right) is speaking to Winter.]] ''Dysfunctional Systems'' is a [[visual novel]] series, where the player reads text to progress the story. At certain points, the novel will present the player with a choice of different dialogue or actions for the series [[protagonist]], Winter Harrison, which will affect events and their consequences. The novel includes a "codex" feature, where the reader can find background information on the current world, such as its geography and politics, as well as topics related to the problems the world is experiencing. The novel also implements a "profile" feature. The choices made during a play-through of an episode can be saved in a profile, such that their consequences can be carried over to the next episode. ==Story== ===Setting and characters=== In ''Dysfunctional Systems'', Earth bears a [[utopia]]n society with a school called "School Mediātōrum", composed of individuals called "mediators". Mediators are humans who resolve chaotic situations in other worlds. Though these worlds exist in different planes, and range in themes from "dystopian, to futuristic or fantastical", it is believed that the chaos of any one world can adversely affect Earth as well. The protagonist of the series, Winter Harrison, is a 14-year-old mediator-in-training. A moral individual, she still finds the concept of "other worlds" hard to grasp.{{cite video game|title=Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos|developer=Dischan Media|publisher=Dischan Media|date=4 April 2013|platform=|version=1.0-1.0.1|scene=|level=|quote='''Winter (internal monologue)''': That's right. I didn't really choose this. I didn't really choose anything. ''[…]'' I couldn't pick a specialty school. I didn't know what I wanted. ''[…]'' "School Mediātōrum"…huh?}} On her second mission (the focus of ''Episode 1'') she is paired with Cyrus Addington, a tough and infamous senior mediator, to act as her guide and mentor.{{cite web|last=Pino|first=Kristina|title=Learning to Manage Chaos|url=http://www.japanator.com/a-look-at-dysfunctional-systems-episode-1-28503.phtml&category=reviews|work=Japanator|publisher=Japanator|accessdate=May 13, 2013|date=25 April 2013}} ===''Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos''=== {{Infobox video game | title = Dysfunctional Systems
Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos | collapsible = yes | state = | image = [[File:Dischan Media - Dysfunctional Systems Ep1.jpeg|250px]] | caption = Dischan Store item panel{{cite web|title=Dischan - Store |url=https://dischan.org/store/ |work=Dischan.org |accessdate=April 20, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930123952/https://dischan.org/store/ |archivedate=September 30, 2013 |df=mdy }} | developer = Dischan Media | publisher = Dischan Media | series = ''Dysfunctional Systems'' | engine = [[Ren'Py]] (Build 6.15.4.320, as of Version 1.0.1){{cite web|last=Miller |first=Jeremy |url=https://dischan.org/devblog/2013/04/learning-to-manage-bugfixes-ds-ep-1-v1-0-1-released/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130714042425/https://dischan.org/devblog/2013/04/learning-to-manage-bugfixes-ds-ep-1-v1-0-1-released/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-07-14 |title=Learning to Manage Bugfixes (DS: EP 1 – v1.0.1 Released) | Devblog |publisher=Dischan.org |date=2013-04-30 |accessdate=2013-07-14 }} | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|PC]]/[[macOS]]/[[Linux]]/[[iOS]] | released = {{Video game release|NA|April 4, 2013{{cite web|url=https://dischan.org/devblog/2013/01/dysfunctional-systems-announcement/|title=Dysfunctional Systems Announcement|last=Miller|first=Jeremy|date=January 5, 2013|work=Dischan|accessdate=January 20, 2013}} (Dischan)
September 26, 2013 (Steam)}} | genre = [[Visual novel]] | director = Jeremy Miller
Terrance Smith
Saimon Ma (visual) | producer = | designer = | programmer = Jeremy Miller
Terrance Smith
Anton Prydatko (iOS version) | artist = Saimon Ma
Eric Tang
Juri Moon | writer = Terrence Smith | composer = Kristian Jensen }} {{cquote|Having long become comfortable with her utopian society, Winter is surprised to learn that there are other worlds in other planes of existence. These worlds are quite different from hers, ranging from troubled, to dystopian, to futuristic or fantastical. However, they are all riddled with problems that, if not resolved, may adversely affect her home world. She is chosen to become a "mediator", charged with the maintenance of order in these chaotic planes, and so enters a vocational school for training. Episode 1 details her second shadowing of a seasoned mediator, only a few weeks into her first year. She and her mentor enter a world seemingly much like their own, except for this issue of "poverty" with which Winter has difficulty understanding...|author=from the official website}} In the first episode, Winter and Cyrus travel to Sule, a sporadically-progressing industrial planet. They arrive in Brighton, a poor and minor country on Sule.{{cite video game|title=Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos|developer=Dischan Media|publisher=Dischan Media|date=April 4, 2013|platform=|version=1.0-1.0.1|scene=|level=|language=|quote=}} There, the two find that the President of Brighton is attempting to negotiate his society's freedom from its oppressor, the wealthy state of Gabrea. The key object of his threat is an untested [[nuclear bomb]], waiting to be launched at Gabrea via [[intercontinental ballistic missile]].{{cite video game|title=Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos|developer=Dischan Media|publisher=Dischan Media|date=April 4, 2013|platform=|version=1.0-1.0.1|scene=|level=Brighton - Bar|language=|quote='''President Barnaby''': ''[over the emergency broadcast channel]'' But I am not her to tell you the troubles of our state. I am not here to tell you the glory of our fathers. I am here to confirm the quiet whispers through the alleys and the worried murmers of Gabrean elite. / '''Winter (narration)''': Pardon? / '''President Barnaby''': Consider this a threat. People of Gabrea, you have four ours to comply with our demands, or a nuclear weapon will be launched at your country. / '''Winter (narration)''': ...That can't be good.}} Cyrus devises a plan to contain the chaos: to [[assassinate]] the President and have him declared a [[martyr]]. Cyrus' plan horrifies Winter; at this point, the player can choose whether Winter will go along with Cyrus' plan, or to rebel against him and try to reason with the President instead.{{cite video game|title=Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos|developer=Dischan Media|publisher=Dischan Media|date=April 4, 2013|platform=|version=1.0-1.0.1|scene=|level=Brighton - Plaza|language=|quote='''Cyrus''': Alright, let's kill the President. ''[...]'' / '''Winter''': '''''What?!'''''}} If Cyrus' plan is taken, the President is killed and his government decides to launch the weapon at Gabrea. If Winter's plan is taken, she and Cyrus manage to convince the President to change his mind and fire his weapon into a nearby sea as a warning shot instead. However, in both cases, the detonation of the weapon goes badly wrong, igniting the atmosphere and completely destroying Sule. Winter and Cyrus are [[Teleportation|teleported]] back to the school on Earth just in time, where they are immediately treated for [[radiation poisoning]] that they had obtained before Sule's destruction. Winter is carried back to her room, where she recounts to her room-mate Waverly of Sule's demise. The next day, Waverly fends off well-wishers from seeing Winter, then helps her to her debriefing, ending the episode. ==Development== In Dischan's earlier work, ''Juniper's Knot'', the player can unlock bonus art featuring the protagonists of the story with two other characters, Winter and Cyrus.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} On January 5, 2013, Dischan leader Jeremy Miller announced the company's first series of visual novels, titled ''Dysfunctional Systems''.{{cite web|url=http://jeremyrmiller.com/project/dysfunctional-systems/ |title=Dysfunctional Systems | Jeremy Miller |publisher=Jeremyrmiller.com |date= |accessdate=June 22, 2013}} On June 5, 2013, Dischan posted Episode 1 of ''Dysfunctional Systems'' on [[Steam Greenlight]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=thl1oGoV3Cw |title=Dysfunctional Systems: Learning to Manage Chaos Gameplay |publisher=Dischan Media|work=[[YouTube]]|date=14 June 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/updates/152499587/1371094539 |title=Discussions |publisher=Steam Community/Dischan Media |date= |accessdate=June 22, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=152499587 |title=Steam Greenlight :: Dysfunctional Systems: Learning to Manage Chaos |publisher=[[Valve Corporation]]/Dischan Media |work=Steamcommunity.com |date= |accessdate=June 22, 2013}} On September 26, 2013, Episode 1 was released on Steam.{{cite web|url=https://dischan.org/devblog/2013/09/dysfunctional-systems-on-steam/ |title=Dysfunctional Systems on Steam! | Devblog |publisher=Dischan.org |date=2013-09-26 |accessdate=2014-03-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111052337/https://dischan.org/devblog/2013/09/dysfunctional-systems-on-steam/ |archivedate=January 11, 2014 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/248800 |title=Dysfunctional Systems: Learning to Manage Chaos on Steam |publisher=Store.steampowered.com |date=2014-02-22 |accessdate=2014-03-18}} ===Kickstarter campaign=== Despite reporting "decent sales" of Episode 1, Dischan admitted that the project was not a financial success. Dischan turned to the crowd-funding site [[Kickstarter]] to raise funds for the production of the second and third installments of the novel. The campaign was opened for funding in February 2014, with the goal of raising [[Canadian dollar|C$]]49,000. By the end of the campaign in March 2014, the campaign had successfully raised C$67,450. Because the original goal was exceeded, Dischan stated that it would add more characters and environments to the second and third episodes than they had originally intended, as well as producing a bonus visual novel depicting Winter's first week as a mediator-in-training.{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dischan/dysfunctional-systems |title=Dysfunctional Systems by Dischan Media — Kickstarter |publisher=Kickstarter.com |date=2014-03-01 |accessdate=2014-03-18}}{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dischan/dysfunctional-systems/posts/781571 |title=Dysfunctional Systems by Dischan Media » FUNDED — Kickstarter |publisher=Kickstarter.com |date=2014-03-01 |accessdate=2014-03-18}} The project was cancelled in a January 2, 2015 announcement by Dischan and began issuing partial refunds through Kickstarter to backers. ===Soundtrack=== The soundtrack to Episode 1, written and performed by Kristian "CombatPlayer" Jensen, was released on 4 April 2013.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} It is distributed with Episode 1 and can also be played in the jukebox within the game. {{Infobox album | name = Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1: Learning to Manage Chaos{{cite web|url=https://dischan.org/store/product.php?productID=8 |title=Dysfunctional Systems: Episode 1 |work=Dischan Media |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |author=CombatPlayer |date=April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130930152318/https://dischan.org/store/product.php?productID=8 |archivedate=September 30, 2013 |df=mdy }} | type = soundtrack | artist = Kristian "CombatPlayer" Jensen | cover = | alt = | released = {{Start date|2013|04|04}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Video game soundtrack | length = 45:04 | label = | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Track listing | collapsed = yes | total_length = 45:04 | title1 = Terminus | note1 = Theme of Episode 1 | length1 = 4:06 | title2 = Turbulence | length2 = 2:12 | title3 = Tempering | length3 = 2:14 | title4 = Looking In | length4 = 2:46 | title5 = Soft Engagement | length5 = 2:12 | title6 = Whisper | length6 = 2:29 | title7 = Analysis | length7 = 1:05 | title8 = Ripple | length8 = 2:01 | title9 = Seize the Day | length9 = 3:23 | title10 = Better get Runnin' | length10 = 2:08 | title11 = Cado Astrum | length11 = 3:29 | title12 = Fragment | length12 = 1:55 | title13 = Hygge | length13 = 2:30 | title14 = Speak Loud | note14 = Rising Superstar Irie | length14 = 4:14 | title15 = Off Time | length15 = 2:27 | title16 = Waverly | length16 = 2:14 | title17 = Maintenance | length17 = 1:58 | title18 = Maintenance | note18 = OP version | length18 = 1:12 }} }} {{-}} ==Reception== ''Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1'' received positive reviews from critics, with the primary issue raised being its brief length. Nadia Oxford of [[Gamezebo]] scored the game 4/5 stars, commending the art, music and story, but criticizing the slow pace and lack of player interaction overall.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezebo.com/games/dysfunctional-systems-episode-1/review |title=Dysfunctional Systems: Episode 1 Review |publisher=Gamezebo |date=April 4, 2013 |accessdate=June 22, 2013}} Andrew Barker of RPGFan scored the game 80/100, saying that while the art was good and the setting and characters showed promise, the game is "held back" by its short length and he recommended players to hold off on purchasing it until the entire game was released.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/Dysfunctional_Systems_Learning_to_Manage_Chaos/index.html|title=RPGFan Review - Dysfunctional Systems: Learning to Manage Chaos|website=www.rpgfan.com|access-date=2017-07-15}} Kristina Pino of [[Destructoid|Japanator]] said that while she liked the artwork, the story "[took] a while to really get moving", and she did not feel a large amount of interest in seeing what happened next, also calling it too short. {{-}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikipedia books|Ren'Py}} {{portal|2010s|Video games|Science fiction}} {{wikiquote}} *{{official website}} *[https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/dischan/dysfunctional-systems Kickstarter page] *{{vndb|11944}} [[Category:2013 video games|Dysfunctional Systems - Episode 1]] [[Category:Ren'Py games and visual novels]] [[Category:Fantasy fiction articles]] [[Category:Dystopian video games]] [[Category:Episodic video games]] [[Category:Utopian fiction]] [[Category:Science fantasy]] [[Category:Science fantasy video games]] [[Category:Steam Greenlight games|DyS Episode 1]] [[Category:Western visual novels]] [[Category:Video game franchises]] [[Category:Parallel universes in fiction]] [[Category:Weapons of mass destruction in fiction]] [[Category:Fictional organizations|School Mediatorum]] [[Category:Wars in fiction]] [[Category:Fiction about assassinations]] [[Category:Robot video games]] [[Category:Kickstarter projects]] [[Category:Crowdfunded video games]] [[Category:Extinction in fiction]] [[Category:Science fiction video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Windows games]]

{{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} ''For other people named Eleazer. see: [[Eleazar (name)]]'' [[File:Plate 15 of 22 for the Macklin Bible after Loutherbourg. Bowyer Bible. Heroism of Eleazar.gif|thumb|''The Heroism of Eleazar'', engraved plate in the [[Thomas Macklin|Macklin]] Bible after a painting by [[Philip James de Loutherbourg]], 1815.]] '''Eleazar Avaran''', also known as '''Eleazar Maccabeus''', '''Eleazar Hachorani/Chorani''' ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: אלעזר המכבי ''Eleazar HaMakabi'', אלעזר החורני ''Eleazar HaChorani''; d. 162 BC) was the fourth son of [[Mattathias]] and the younger brother of [[Judas Maccabeus]]. He was killed at the [[Battle of Beth-zechariah]] ({{Bibleverse|1|Maccabees|6:32-33|NRSV}}) during the [[Maccabean revolt]].
Little is known About Eleazar, except his heroic death as was told. According to the scroll of Antichus, his father saw in him a [[Kanai (Judaism)|Zealot]] among zealots, like [[Pinhas]]. In {{Bibleverse|2|Maccabees|8:21-23|NRSV}} it is told that Eleazar read from the [[Tanakh]] in front of the people just before the last battle began in {{Bibleverse|3|Maccabees|6:16-19|NRSV}}.
==Death== According to {{Bibleverse|1|Maccabees|6:43-46|NRSV}}, during the [[Battle of Beth Zechariah|Battle of Beit Zechariah]], Eleazar identified a [[war elephant]] that he believed to carry the [[Seleucid]] King [[Antiochus V]], due to the special armor the elephant wore. He decided to endanger his life by attacking the elephant and thrusting a spear into its belly. The dead elephant then collapsed upon Eleazar, killing him as well.<ref>{{cite book|last=Scullard|first=Howard Hayes|title=The Elephant in the Greek and Roman World|year=1974|publisher=Cornell Univ Press|isbn=978-0801409318|pages=186|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_elephant_in_the_Greek_and_Roman_worl.html?id=zzNoAAAAMAAJ}}</ref> Despite this heroic effort, the smaller Jewish army was defeated in the battle. [[Josephus]] wrote that Eleazar, though killing many enemy soldiers, did not gain any real effect besides the name he made for himself. In another variation of this story which appears in the [[Scroll of Antiochus|Megillat Antiochus]], Eleazar's body is discovered after sinking in the excrement of an elephant.<ref>{{cite book|title=Megillat Antiochus|date=1851|publisher=Jewish Antiquarian Society|location=London|url=http://www.hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=33150&st=&pgnum=22&hilite=}}</ref>
==Avaran== [[File:IRHT 126277-p.jpg|thumb|Miniature from a manuscript ''[[Speculum Humanae Salvationis]]''. Eleazar kills the elephant and is crushed.]] All of the members of the family of [[Mattathias]] were given nicknames in addition to their [[personal names]] as can be seen in {{Bibleverse|1|Maccabees|2:1-5|NRSV}} (For example, [[Judas Maccabeus|Judas]] was given the name 'ha'Makabi', meaning 'the Hammer'.) Eleazar was given the name 'Avaran', which has been taken to mean 'the Piercer' (in reference to his death) or 'to be white' (referring to his light complexion).<ref>{{cite web|title=Avaran|url=https://net.bible.org/#!l/dictionary%3Aavaran__search%3Aavaran|work=Net Bible|publisher=Bible.org|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref>
==Commemoration== Eleazar's death was a popular subject for art in the [[Middle Ages]], where it was given a [[typology (theology)|typological]] significance as prefiguring Christ's sacrifice of himself for mankind.<ref>{{cite web|title=Speculum Woodcuts and Miniatures|url=http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft7v19p1w6&chunk.id=d0e4325|work=UC Press E-Books Collection, 1982-2004|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref> The chance to portray an elephant was also welcomed by artists, although as most had never seen one, the results are often very strange. It is also portrayed in a painting of 19th century [[France|French]] [[artist]] [[Gustave Doré]].
The [[Israeli settlement]], [[Elazar (village)|Elazar]], in [[Gush Etzion]], near the site of the [[battle of Beth-zechariah]], is named after him. Also there are streets named after him in [[Jerusalem]] and in [[Tel Aviv]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Eleazar Maccabeus}} *[http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/collections/fortitude/whoswho.asp Tapestry with Eleazer killing the elephant]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Avaran, Eleazar}} [[Category:162 BC deaths]] [[Category:Hasmonean dynasty]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]] [[Category:People in the Deuterocanonical books]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Maccabees]] [[Category:2nd-century BCE Jews]]

{{Infobox horseracing personality |name = Emanuel Jose Sanchez |image = |caption = |occupation = [[Jockey]] |birth_place = [[Carolina, Puerto Rico]] |birth_date = September 21, 1982 |death_date = July 23, 2005 |career wins = 1 |race = Race #7 at [[Colonial Downs]] on June 19, 2005 |awards = |honours = |horses = Mark Me Special |updated = }} '''Emanuel Jose Sanchez''' (September 21, 1982 – July 23, 2005) was a [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]] [[jockey]] competing in [[United States|American]] [[Thoroughbred horse race|Thoroughbred horse racing]].
Born in [[Carolina, Puerto Rico]], Sanchez emigrated to the [[United States]] where he worked as an exercise rider at Bowie Training Center in [[Bowie, Maryland]] and had raced at other Thoroughbred racetracks. In the summer of 2005 he was working as an apprentice jockey at [[Colonial Downs]] racetrack in [[New Kent County, Virginia]].
Like many jockeys, Emanuel Jose Sanchez struggled to maintain his weight to meet the requirements for racing. According to Christian Olmo, a fellow Puerto Rican jockey and close friend who grew up with Sanchez, he had no visions of grandeur but had a passion for riding horses. Sanchez won one race during his short career in the United States. Riding the [[Mare (horse)|mare]] Mark Me Special he captured the 7th race at Colonial Downs on June 19, 2005. According to the [[Washington Post]], "Sanchez was so unsteady after crossing the finish line at Colonial Downs, he needed help guiding the horse into the winner's circle". On a hot Friday, July 22, shortly after riding a horse named Bear On Tour in the fourth race at Colonial Downs, Sanchez was found collapsed on the floor of the [[shower]] in the jockey's room. Rushed to Richmond Community Hospital in [[Richmond, Virginia]], he died on Saturday morning from the effects of [[dehydration]]. His death as a result of dieting was the first of two in 2005. On November 12, [[Louisville, Kentucky]] jockey [[Chris Herrell]] also died as a result of crash dieting.
Emanuel Jose Sanchez's remains were returned to his native [[Puerto Rico]] for burial. According to friend Christian Olmo, he is survived by a 6-year-old daughter.
==References== * [http://cbs.sportsline.com/horseracing/story/8675385 July 25, 2005 CBS Sportsline article titled ''Jockey, 22, dies after Colonial Downs race''] * [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=2118167&type=story July 27, 2005 ESPN article titled ''Jockey's tragic death shows that weights must change''] * [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/24/AR2005072401110.html July 25, 2005 ''Washington Post'' report by John Scheinman on the death of Emanuel Jose Sanchez]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sanchez}} [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths by starvation]] [[Category:Puerto Rican jockeys]] [[Category:American jockeys]] [[Category:People from Carolina, Puerto Rico]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{about||the opera|Fausta (opera)|the Catholic saint|Saint Fausta}} {{Infobox royalty | consort=yes | name =Fausta | image =P1070865 Louvre tête de Fausta Ma4881 rwk.JPG | caption =Fausta, most probably before her marriage to Constantine I, [[The Louvre]] museum. | succession =[[Empress]] of the [[Roman Empire]] | reign =300 - 326 | spouse =[[Constantine I]] | issue =[[Constantina]]
[[Constantine II (emperor)|Constantine II, Roman Emperor]]
[[Constantius II|Constantius II, Roman Emperor]]
[[Constans|Constans, Roman Emperor]]
[[Helena, wife of Julian|Helena, Roman Empress]]
Fausta | house =[[Constantinian dynasty|Constantinian]] | house-type = Dynasty | father =[[Maximianus (emperor)|Maximian, Roman Emperor]] | mother =[[Eutropia]] | birth_date =289 | birth_place =[[Rome]], [[Italy]] | death_date ={{death year and age|326|289}} | death_place= | place of burial= | religion = | full name= }} '''Flavia Maxima Fausta''' (289–326) was a Roman Empress, daughter of the [[Roman Emperor]] [[Maximianus (emperor)|Maximianus]]. To seal the alliance between them for control of the [[Tetrarchy]], in 307 Maximianus married her to [[Constantine I]], who set aside his wife [[Minervina]] in her favour. Constantine and Fausta had been betrothed since 293. ==Life== [[File:Follis-Fausta-constantinople RIC 012.jpg|thumb|left|Fausta, as [[Salus]], holding her two sons, [[Constantine II (emperor)|Constantine II]] and [[Constantius II]].]] As the sister of Emperor Maxentius, Fausta had a part in her father's downfall. In 310 Maximian died as a consequence of an assassination plot against Constantine. Maximian decided to involve his daughter Fausta, but she revealed the plot to her husband, and the assassination was disrupted. Maximian died, by suicide or by assassination, in July of that same year. Empress Fausta was held in high esteem by Constantine, and proof of his favour was that in 324 On 8 November 324 according to Prof. Dr. Dr. Klaus Rosen, ''Konstantin der Grosse: Kaiser zwischen Machtpolitik und Religion'', Klett-Cotta, Stuttgart 2013, {{ISBN|978-3-608-94050-3}}, page 248–249. she was proclaimed [[Augusta (honorific)|Augusta]]; previously she held the title of Nobilissima Femina. However, in 326, Fausta was put to death by Constantine, following the execution of [[Crispus]], his eldest son by Minervina. The two deaths have been inter-related in various ways; in one, Fausta is set jealously against Crispus, as in the anonymous ''Epitome de Caesaribus'',41.11–12; According to some sources, she had accused Crispus of rape, and Constantine had Crispus executed. Stephenson remarks that if Fausta had reported a false tale of treachery and was killed in Constantine's subsequent remorse, the ''damnatio memoriae'' against Crispus was not in fact repealed. or conversely her adultery, perhaps with the stepson who was close to her in age, is suggested. According to the Latin ''Epitome de Caesaribus'' and the ''[http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/philostorgius.htm Ecclesiastical History]'' of Philostorgius (as epitomized by Photius), Fausta was executed by being cast into boiling water,{{Cite book|title=Die Epitome de Caesaribus. Untersuchungen zur heidnischen Geschichtsschreibung des 4. Jahrhunderts n. Chr.|last=Schlumberger:|first=Jörg A.|publisher=C.H. Beck|year=1974|isbn=|location=Munich|pages=41.11-12}} in connection with the death of Crispus, whose death was reportedly caused be her allegations of sexual impropriety.{{Cite journal|last=Woods|first=D.|date=1998|title=On the Death of the Empress Fausta.|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/3CE624703CA80405ACBFBB40EA629FCC/S0017383500029156a.pdf/on_the_death_of_the_empress_fausta.pdf|journal=Greece and Rome,|volume=45.1|pages=70-86|via=}} The mode of assassination not otherwise attested in the Roman world. David Woods offers the connection of overheated bathing with contemporaneous techniques of abortion,Woods,"On the death of the empress Fausta", ''Greece and Rome'' '''45''' (1998:70–86). a suggestion that implies an unwanted, adulterous pregnancy according to Constantine's biographer Paul Stephenson.Stephenson 2010:222. The Emperor ordered the [[damnatio memoriae]] of his wife with the result that no contemporary source records details of her fate: "[[Eusebius of Caesarea|Eusebius]], ever the sycophant, mentions neither Crispus nor Fausta in his ''Life of Constantine'', and even wrote Crispus out of the final version of his ''Ecclesiastical History'' (''HE'' X.9.4)", Constantine's biographer Paul Stephenson observes.Stephenson, ''Constantine, Roman Emperor, Christian Victor'', 2010:220. Significantly, her sons, once in power, never revoked this order. Her sons became Roman Emperors: [[Constantine II (emperor)|Constantine II]], reigned 337 – 340, [[Constantius II]] reigned 337 – 361, and [[Constans]] reigned 337 – 350. She also bore three daughters [[Constantina]], [[Helena, wife of Julian|Helena]] and Fausta. Of these, Constantina married her cousins, firstly [[Hannibalianus]] and secondly [[Constantius Gallus]], and Helena married Emperor [[Julian (emperor)|Julian]]. Apparently a genealogical claim that her daughter Fausta became mother of Emperor [[Valentinian I]] is without foundation (Valentinian I and the children of Constantine I's second marriage were born in years close to each other, i.e., they were of the same generation). ==References== {{reflist}} == Bibliography == *{{fr icon}} Gérard Minaud, ''Les vies de 12 femmes d’empereur romain - Devoirs, Intrigues & Voluptés '', Paris, L’Harmattan, 2012, ch. 12, '' La vie de Fausta, femme de Constantin'', p. 285-305. * J.W. Drijvers, 'Flavia Maxima Fausta: Some Remarks', ''Historia'' 41 (1992) 500- 506. == External links == * {{Commons-inline|Fausta}} * {{Cite Americana|wstitle=Fausta, Flavia Maximiana|short=x}} {{s-start}} {{s-roy}} {{s-bef|before=[[Galeria Valeria]]
(or [[Minervina]])}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Empress of Rome]]|years=307–326|regent1=[[Galeria Valeria]]|years1=307–311|regent2=[[Valeria Maximilla]]|years2=307–312|regent3=[[Flavia Julia Constantia]]|years3=313–324}} {{s-aft|after=[[Daughter of Julius Constantius]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:289 births]] [[Category:326 deaths]] [[Category:Constantinian dynasty]] [[Category:Flavii]] [[Category:Roman empresses]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:Executed Roman empresses]] [[Category:Murdered Roman empresses]] [[Category:3rd-century Romans]] [[Category:4th-century Romans]] [[Category:3rd-century Roman women]] [[Category:4th-century Roman women]] [[Category:Constantine the Great]] [[Category:4th-century executions]] [[Category:People executed by the Roman Empire]] [[Category:Damnatio memoriae]]

{{unreferenced|date=November 2007}} {{ infobox nobility | name = Frederick I, Count of Vaudémont | image = | caption = | noble family = [[House of Lorraine]] | father = [[John I, Duke of Lorraine]] | mother = Sophie of Württemberg | spouse = [[Margaret of Joinville]] | birth_date = 1371 | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date|1415|10|25|df=y}} | death_place = [[Azincourt|Agincourt]] }}
'''Frederick of Lorraine''' (1371 – October 25, 1415 in the [[battle of Agincourt]]) was a [[Count of Vaudémont]].
He was the son of Duke [[John I, Duke of Lorraine|John I of Lorraine]] and younger brother of [[Charles II, Duke of Lorraine|Charles II]]. In 1393, Frederick married [[Margaret of Joinville|Margaret]] the heiress of Vaudémont and Joinville, and became Count of these lands [[jure uxoris|in her right]]. He founded the [[House of Vaudémont]], a junior branch of the [[House of Lorraine]].
His children were: *[[Antoine, Count of Vaudémont|Antoine]], who succeeded as Count of Vaudémont, *[[Elisabeth of Lorraine-Vaudémont|Elisabeth]], who married [[Philipp I of Nassau-Weilburg]], and *Margaret, who married Thibault II of Blamont.
Dynastic problems in the senior line caused his great-grandson [[René II, Duke of Lorraine|René of Vaudémont]] to become [[Duke of Lorraine]] as René II in 1473.
==See also== *[[Dukes of Lorraine family tree]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Frederick 01, Count Of Vaudemont}} [[Category:House of Vaudémont]] [[Category:Counts of Vaudémont]] [[Category:1371 births]] [[Category:1415 deaths]] [[Category:Military personnel killed in action]]
{{Europe-noble-stub}}

'''Gnotobiosis''' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] roots ''gnostos'' "known" and ''bios'' "life") is a condition in which all the forms of life present within an [[organism]] can be accounted for. Typically gnotobiotic organisms are [[germ-free animal|germ-free]] or [[gnotophoric]] (having only one contaminant).
==Gnotobiotic animals== A '''gnotobiotic animal''' is an animal in which only certain known strains of [[bacteria]] and other microorganisms are present. Technically, the term also includes [[germ-free animal|germ-free]] animals, as the status of their microbial communities is also ''known''.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Reyniers JA |title=Germfree Vertebrates: Present Status |year=1959 |journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences |volume=78 |issue=1 |pages=3 |doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1959.tb53091.x}}</ref> However, the term ''gnotobiotic'' is often incorrectly contrasted with ''germ-free''.
Gnotobiotic animals (also "gnotobiotes" or "gnotobionts") are born in [[aseptic technique|aseptic]] conditions, which may include removal from the mother by [[Caesarean section]] and immediate transfer of the newborn to an isolator where all incoming air, food and water is sterilized.<ref name=Foster>{{cite book|author1=Foster, John W. |author2=Slonczewski, Joan L.|title=Microbiology, An Evolving Science|year=2009|publisher=W. W. Norton|isbn=978-0-393-93447-2|pages=871}}</ref> Such animals are normally reared in a sterile or microbially-controlled laboratory environment, and they are only exposed to those microorganisms that the researchers wish to have present in the animal. These gnotobiotes are used to study the [[symbiosis|symbiotic]] relationships between an animal and one or more of the microorganisms that may inhabit its body. This technique is important for microbiologists because it allows them to study only a select few symbiotic interactions at a time (see [[Scientific control]]), whereas animals that develop under normal conditions may quickly acquire a [[microflora|microbiota]] that includes hundreds or thousands of unique organisms.
Animals reared in a gnotobiotic colony often have poorly developed immune systems, lower [[cardiac output]], thin intestinal walls and high susceptibility to infectious [[pathogens]].<ref name=Foster/>
Such animals may also be used in animal production, especially in the rearing of pigs. After the Caesarean birth, these animals are introduced to their natural microflora in a stepwise fashion. This avoids undesired infections and leads to faster growth.
==See also== * [[Specific-pathogen-free]] (SPF) * [[Axenic culture]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Ecology terminology]] [[Category:Model organisms]]
{{Biology-stub}}
