revision.text:
{{Psychology sidebar}} '''Social dominance orientation''' ('''SDO''')<ref name="Sidanius2001">{{cite book|last1=Sidanius |first1= Jim |last2= Pratto |first2= Felicia |year= 2001 |title=Social Dominance: An Intergroup Theory of Social Hierarchy and Oppression |location=Cambridge |publisher= Cambridge University Press | isbn =978-0-521-80540-7 }}{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref> is a personality trait which predicts social and political attitudes, and is a widely used [[Social Psychology|social psychological]] scale. SDO is conceptualized as a measure of individual differences in levels of group-based discrimination; that is, it is a measure of an individual's preference for [[hierarchy]] within any [[social system]] and the domination over lower-status groups. It is a predisposition toward anti-[[egalitarianism]] within and between groups. The concept of SDO as a measurable individual difference is a product of [[social dominance theory]].
Individuals who score high in SDO desire to maintain and, in many cases, increase the differences between [[social status]]es of different groups, as well as individual group members. Typically, they are dominant, driven, tough, and seekers of [[Power (social and political)|power]]. People high in SDO also prefer hierarchical group orientations. Often, people who score high in SDO adhere strongly to belief in a "[[wiktionary:dog eat dog|dog-eat-dog]]" world.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0146167202282002 |title=Social Dominance Orientation and Intergroup Bias: The Legitimation of Favoritism for High-Status Groups |year=2002 |last1=Levin |first1=S. |last2=Federico |first2=C. M. |last3=Sidanius |first3=J. |last4=Rabinowitz |first4=J. L. |journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=144–57}}</ref> It has also been found that men are generally higher than women in SDO measures.<ref>Forsyth, D.R. (2009). ''Ground Dynamics'': New York: Wadsworth [Chapter 7]{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref> Studies have found that SDO has a strong positive relationship with [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] and [[Racism|racist]] beliefs.<ref name="auth">{{cite journal |url=http://bartduriez.com/documents/PDF/2002_DuriezVanhiel.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203010927/http://bartduriez.com/documents/PDF/2002_DuriezVanhiel.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-02-03 |title=The march of modern fascism. A comparison of social dominance orientation and authoritarianism |year=2002 |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=32 |issue=7 |pages=1199–1213 |last1=Duriez |first1=Bart |last2=Van Hiel |first2=Alain |doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(01)00086-1 |citeseerx=10.1.1.1005.399 }}</ref>
==Social dominance theory==
SDO was first proposed by Jim Sidanius and Felicia Pratto as part of their [[social dominance theory]] (SDT). SDO is the key measurable component of SDT that is specific to it.
SDT begins with the empirical observation that surplus-producing social systems have a threefold group-based hierarchy structure: age-based, gender-based and "arbitrary set-based", which can include race, class, sexual orientation, caste, ethnicity, religious affiliation, etc. Age-based hierarchies invariably give more power to adults and middle-age people than children and younger adults, and gender-based hierarchies invariably grant more power to one [[gender]] over others, but arbitrary-set hierarchies—though quite resilient—are truly arbitrary.
SDT is based on three primary assumptions:{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} #While age- and gender-based hierarchies will tend to exist within all social systems, arbitrary-set systems of social hierarchy will invariably emerge within social systems producing sustainable economic surpluses. #Most forms of group conflict and oppression (e.g., racism, homophobia, ethnocentrism, sexism, classism, regionalism) can be regarded as different manifestations of the same basic human predisposition to form group-based hierarchies. #Human social systems are subject to the counterbalancing influences of hierarchy-enhancing (HE) forces, producing and maintaining ever higher levels of group-based social inequality, and hierarchy-attenuating (HA) forces, producing greater levels of group-based social equality.
SDO is the individual attitudinal aspect of SDT. It is influenced by group status, socialization, and temperament. In turn, it influences support for HE and HA "legitimating myths", defined as "values, attitudes, beliefs, causal attributions and ideologies" that in turn justify social institutions and practices that either enhance or attenuate group hierarchy.
==Early development== While the correlation of gender with SDO scores has been empirically measured and confirmed,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.2044-8309.1997.tb01118.x |title=The gender gap: Differences in political attitudes and social dominance orientation |year=1997 |last1=Pratto |first1=Felicia |last2=Stallworth |first2=Lisa M. |last3=Sidanius |first3=Jim |journal=British Journal of Social Psychology |volume=36 |pages=49–68 |pmid=9114484}}</ref> the impact of temperament and socialization is less clear. Duckitt has suggested a model of attitude development for SDO, suggesting that unaffectionate socialisation in childhood causes a tough-minded attitude. According to Duckitt's model, people high in tough-minded personality are predisposed to view the world as a competitive place in which resource competition is [[zero-sum]]. A desire to compete, which fits with social dominance orientation, influences in-group and outside-group attitudes. People high in SDO also believe that hierarchies are present in all aspects of society and are more likely to agree with statements such as "It's probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom". In turn, SDO predicts stereotyping, discrimination and prejudice.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}}
==Scale==
SDO has been measured by a series of scales that have been refined over time, all of which contain a balance of pro- and contra-trait statements or phrases. A 7-point [[Likert scale]] is used for each item; participants rate their agreement or disagreement with the statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). Most of the research was conducted with the SDO-5 (a 14-point scale) and SDO-6. The SDO-7 scale is the most recent scale measuring social dominance orientation, which embeds two sub-dimensions: dominance (SDO-D) and anti-egalitarianism (SDO-E).<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Ho|first=Arnold K.|last2=Sidanius|first2=Jim|last3=Kteily|first3=Nour|last4=Sheehy-Skeffington|first4=Jennifer|last5=Pratto|first5=Felicia|last6=Henkel|first6=Kristin E.|last7=Foels|first7=Rob|last8=Stewart|first8=Andrew L.|title=The nature of social dominance orientation: Theorizing and measuring preferences for intergroup inequality using the new SDO₇ scale.|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=109|issue=6|pages=1003–1028|doi=10.1037/pspi0000033|pmid=26479362|year=2015}}</ref>
=== SDO-7 items<ref name=":5" /> ===
==== Dominance Sub-Scale ==== # Some groups of people must be kept in their place. # It's probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom. # An ideal society requires some groups to be on top and others to be on the bottom. # Some groups of people are simply inferior to other groups. # Groups at the bottom are just as deserving as groups at the top. (reverse-scored) # No one group should dominate in society. (reverse-scored) # Groups at the bottom should not have to stay in their place. (reverse-scored) # Group dominance is a poor principle. (reverse-scored)
==== Anti-Egalitarianism Sub-Scale ==== # We should not push for group equality. # We shouldn't try to guarantee that every group has the same quality of life. # It is unjust to try to make groups equal. # Group equality should not be our primary goal. # We should work to give all groups an equal chance to succeed. (reverse-scored) # We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups. (reverse-scored) # No matter how much effort it takes, we ought to strive to ensure that all groups have the same chance in life. (reverse-scored) # Group equality should be our ideal. (reverse-scored)
=== SDO-16 items<ref name="Sidanius2001" />===
# Some groups of people are simply inferior to other groups. # In getting what you want, it is sometimes necessary to use force against other groups. # It's OK if some groups have more of a chance in life than others. # To get ahead in life, it is sometimes necessary to step on other groups. # If certain groups stayed in their place, we would have fewer problems. # It's probably a good thing that certain groups are at the top and other groups are at the bottom. # Inferior groups should stay in their place. # Sometimes other groups must be kept in their place. # It would be good if groups could be equal. (reverse-scored) # Group equality should be our ideal. (reverse-scored) # All groups should be given an equal chance in life. (reverse-scored) # We should do what we can to equalize conditions for different groups. (reverse-scored) # Increased social equality is beneficial to society. (reverse-scored) # We would have fewer problems if we treated people more equally. (reverse-scored) # We should strive to make incomes as equal as possible. (reverse-scored) # No group should dominate in society. (reverse-scored)
Keying is reversed on questions 9 through 16, to control for [[acquiescence bias]].
==Criticisms of the construct== Rubin and Hewstone (2004)<ref name=Rubin2004>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9221.2004.00400.x |title=Social Identity, System Justification, and Social Dominance: Commentary on Reicher, Jost et al., and Sidanius et al |year=2004 |last1=Rubin |first1=Mark |last2=Hewstone |first2=Miles |journal=Political Psychology |volume=25 |issue=6 |pages=823–44}}</ref> argue that social dominance research has changed its focus dramatically over the years, and these changes have been reflected in different versions of the social dominance orientation construct. Social dominance orientation was originally defined as "the degree to which individuals desire social dominance and superiority for themselves and their primordial groups over other groups" (p. 209).<ref name=Sidanius1993>{{cite book |last1=Sidanius |first1=James |chapter=The psychology of group conflict and the dynamics of oppression: A social dominance perspective |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=Io8pP8ihLg4C&pg=PA183 |editor1-last=Iyengar |editor1-first=Shanto |editor2-last=McGuire |editor2-first=William James |year=1993 |title=Explorations in political psychology. Duke studies in political psychology |pages=183–219 |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-1324-3}}</ref> It then quickly changed to not only "(a) a…desire for and value given to in-group dominance over out-groups" but also "(b) the desire for nonegalitarian, hierarchical relationships between groups within the social system" (p. 1007).<ref name=Sidanius1994>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.67.6.998 |title=Social dominance orientation and the political psychology of gender: A case of invariance? |year=1994 |last1=Sidanius |first1=Jim |last2=Pratto |first2=Felicia |last3=Bobo |first3=Lawrence |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=67 |issue=6 |pages=998–1011}}</ref> The most recent measure of social dominance orientation (see SDO-6 above) focuses on the "general desire for unequal relations among social groups, regardless of whether this means ingroup domination or ingroup subordination" (p. 312).<ref name=Sidanius>{{cite book |last1=Sidanius |first1=Jim |last2=Levin |first2=Shana |last3=Federico |first3=Christopher M. |last4=Pratt |first4=Felicia |year=2001 |chapter=Legitimizing Ideologies: The Social Dominance Approach |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=wazaJn0Dh90C&pg=PA307 |pages=307–31 |editor1-first=John T. |editor1-last=Jost |editor2-first=Brenda |editor2-last=Major |title=The Psychology of Legitimacy: Emerging Perspectives on Ideology, Justice, and Intergroup Relations |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-78699-7}}</ref> Given these changes, Rubin and Hewstone believe that evidence for social dominance theory should be considered "as supporting three separate SDO hypotheses, rather than one single theory" (p. 22).<ref name=Rubin2004/>
==Group-based and individual dominance==
Robert Altemeyer said that people with a high SDO want more power (agreeing with items such as "''Winning is more important than how you play the game''") and are more [[Machiavellianism|Machiavellian]] (manipulative and amoral, agreeing with items such as "''There really is no such thing as'' 'right and wrong' and ''It all boils down to what you can get away with''").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://members.shaw.ca/jeanaltemeyer/drbob/TheAuthoritarians.pdf |title=The Authoritarians |page=166 |last=Altemeyer |first=Robert |authorlink=Bob Altemeyer |year=2006 |format=PDF |accessdate=20 March 2016}}{{page needed|date=November 2013}}</ref>
These observations are at odds with conceptualisations of SDO as a group-based phenomenon, suggesting that the SDO reflects interpersonal dominance, not only group-based dominance. This is supported by Sidanius and Pratto's own evidence that high-SDO individuals tend to gravitate toward hierarchy-enhancing jobs and institutions, such as law enforcement, that are themselves hierarchically structured vis-a-vis individuals within them.
==Relations with other personality traits==
===Connection with right wing authoritarianism===
SDO correlates weakly with [[right-wing authoritarianism]] (RWA) ([[Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient|r]] ≈ .18).<ref name=pratto /> Both predict attitudes, such as [[sexist]], [[racist]], and [[Heterosexism|heterosexist]] attitudes.<ref name=Sibley2006>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9221.2006.00531.x |title=Social Dominance Orientation and Right-Wing Authoritarianism: Additive and Interactive Effects |year=2006 |last1=Sibley |first1=Chris G. |last2=Robertson |first2=Andrew |last3=Wilson |first3=Marc S. |journal=Political Psychology |volume=27 |issue=5 |pages=755–68 |jstor=3792537}}</ref> The two contribute to different forms of prejudice; SDO correlates to higher prejudice against subordinate and disadvantaged groups, RWA correlates to higher prejudice against threatening groups, while both are associated with increases in prejudice for "dissident" groups.<ref name=crawford2013>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1559-1816.2012.00990.x |title=Right-wing authoritarianism and social dominance orientation differentially predict biased evaluations of media reports |year=2013 |last1=Crawford |first1=Jarret T. |last2=Jussim |first2=Lee |last3=Cain |first3=Thomas R. |last4=Cohen |first4=Florette |journal=Journal of Applied Social Psychology |volume=43 |pages=163–74}}</ref><ref name=Duckitt2007>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/per.614 |title=Right wing authoritarianism, social dominance orientation and the dimensions of generalized prejudice |year=2007 |last1=Duckitt |first1=John |last2=Sibley |first2=Chris G. |journal=European Journal of Personality |volume=21 |issue=2 |pages=113–30}}</ref><ref name= Asbrock2009>{{cite journal |doi=10.1002/per.746 |title=Right-wing authoritarianism and social dominance orientation and the dimensions of generalized prejudice: A longitudinal test |year=2009 |last1=Asbrock |first1=Frank |last2=Sibley |first2=Chris G. |last3=Duckitt |first3=John |journal=European Journal of Personality |pages=324–40}}</ref> SDO and RWA contribute to [[prejudice]] in an additive rather than interactive way (the interaction{{clarify|date=May 2012}} of SDO and RWA accounted, in one study, for an average of less than .001% variance in addition to their linear combination), that is the association between SDO and prejudice is similar regardless of a person's level of RWA, and vice versa.<ref name=Sibley2006/> Crawford et al. (2013) found that RWA and SDO differentially predicted interpretations of media reports about socially threatening (for example, gays and lesbians) and disadvantaged groups (for example, African Americans), respectively. Subjects with high SDO, but not RWA, scores reacted positively to articles and authors that opposed [[affirmative action]], and negatively to pro-affirmative-action article content. Moreover, RWA, but not SDO, predicted subjects' evaluations of same-sex relationships, such that high-RWA individuals favored anti-same-sex relationships article content and low-RWA individuals favorably rated pro-same-sex relationships content.<ref name=crawford2013/>
===Correlation with Big Five personality traits===
Studies on the relationship of SDO with the higher order [[Big Five personality traits]] have associated high SDO with lower [[openness to experience]] and lower [[agreeableness]].<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/per.526|last1=Ekehammar|first1=Bo|last2=Akrami|first2=Nazar|last3=Gylje|first3=Magnus|last4=Zakrisson|first4=Ingrid|title=What matters most to prejudice: Big Five personality, Social Dominance Orientation, or Right-Wing Authoritarianism?|journal=European Journal of Personality|volume=18|issue=6|pages=463–482|year=2004}}</ref> [[Meta-analysis|Meta-analytic]] aggregation of these studies indicates that the association with low Agreeableness is more robust than the link to Openness to experience.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Right-Wing Authoritarianism and Social Dominance Orientation|journal = Journal of Individual Differences|date = 2006-01-01|issn = 1614-0001|pages = 117–126|volume = 27|issue = 3|doi = 10.1027/1614-0001.27.3.117|first = Nazar|last = Akrami|first2 = Bo|last2 = Ekehammar}}</ref> Individuals low in Agreeableness are more inclined to report being motivated by self-interest and self-indulgence''.''<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Big-Five personality prospectively predicts Social Dominance Orientation and Right-Wing Authoritarianism|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886911003825|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|date = 2012-01-01|pages = 3–8|volume = 52|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2011.08.009|first = Ryan|last = Perry|first2 = Chris G.|last2 = Sibley}}</ref> They also tend to be more self-centred and are more '[[Psychoticism|tough-minded]]' compared to those who are high on Agreeableness, leading them to perceive the world to be a highly-competitive place, where the way to success is through power and dominance – all of which predict SDO.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Personality and Prejudice: A Meta-Analysis and Theoretical Review|url = http://psr.sagepub.com/content/12/3/248|journal = Personality and Social Psychology Review|date = 2008-08-01|issn = 1088-8683|pmid = 18641385|pages = 248–279|volume = 12|issue = 3|doi = 10.1177/1088868308319226|first = Chris G.|last = Sibley|first2 = John|last2 = Duckitt}}</ref>
Low Openness, by contrast, aligns more strongly with RWA; thinking in clear and straightforward moral codes that dictate how society as a system should function. Being low in Openness prompts the individual to value security, stability and control: fundamental elements of RWA.<ref name=":1" />
==== Facet-level associations ====
In case of SDO all five facets of Agreeableness significantly correlate (negatively), even after controlling for RWA.<ref name=":0" /> 'Tough-mindedness' (opposite of tender-mindedness' facet) is the strongest predictor of SDO. After the effect of SDO is controlled for only one facet of agreeableness is predictive of RWA. {{Citation needed|date = December 2015}} Facets also distinguish SDO from RWA, with 'Dominators' (individuals high on SDO), but not 'authoritarians' (individuals who score high on RWA), having been found to be lower in dutifulness, morality, sympathy and co-operation.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Right-wing authoritarianism, social dominance orientation and personality: an analysis using the IPIP measure|journal = European Journal of Personality|date = 2001-01-01|issn = 1099-0984|pages = 49–56|volume = 15|issue = 1|doi = 10.1002/per.389|first = Patrick C. L.|last = Heaven|first2 = Sandra|last2 = Bucci}}</ref> RWA is also associated with religiosity, conservativism, righteousness, and, to some extent, a conscientious moral code, which distinguishes RWA from SDO.
=== Empathy === SDO is inversely related to [[empathy]]. Facets of Agreeableness that are linked to [[altruism]], sympathy and compassion are the strongest predictors of SDO.<ref name="pratto" /> SDO has been suggested to have a link with callous affect (which is to be found on the [[psychopathy]] sub-scale), the 'polar opposite' of empathy.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The role of "dark personalities" (narcissism, Machiavellianism, psychopathy), Big Five personality factors, and ideology in explaining prejudice|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092656609000658|journal = Journal of Research in Personality|date = 2009-08-01|pages = 686–690|volume = 43|issue = 4|doi = 10.1016/j.jrp.2009.02.005|first = Gordon|last = Hodson|first2 = Sarah M.|last2 = Hogg|first3 = Cara C.|last3 = MacInnis}}</ref>
The relationship between SDO and ''(lack of)'' empathy has been found to be reciprocal <ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = You're Inferior and Not Worth Our Concern: The Interface Between Empathy and Social Dominance Orientation|journal = Journal of Personality|date = 2013-06-01|issn = 1467-6494|pages = 313–323|volume = 81|issue = 3|doi = 10.1111/jopy.12008|pmid = 23072294|first = Jim|last = Sidanius|first2 = Nour|last2 = Kteily|first3 = Jennifer|last3 = Sheehy-Skeffington|first4 = Arnold K.|last4 = Ho|first5 = Chris|last5 = Sibley|first6 = Bart|last6 = Duriez}}</ref> – with equivocal findings. Some studies show that empathy significantly impacts SDO,<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = Structural Modeling of Generalized Prejudice|journal = Journal of Individual Differences|date = 2007-01-01|issn = 1614-0001|pages = 10–17|volume = 28|issue = 1|doi = 10.1027/1614-0001.28.1.10|first = Martin|last = Bäckström|first2 = Fredrik|last2 = Björklund}}</ref> whereas other research suggest the opposite effect is more robust; that SDO predicts empathy.<ref name=":2" /> The latter showcases how powerful of a predictor SDO may be, not only affecting individual's certain behaviours, but potentially influencing upstream the proneness to those behaviours. It also suggests, that those scoring high on SDO proactively avoid scenarios that could prompt them to be more empathetic or tender-minded. This avoidance decreases concern for other's welfare.<ref name=":2" />
Empathy indirectly affects generalized [[prejudice]] through its negative relationship with SDO.<ref name=":3" /> It also has a direct effect on generalized prejudice, as lack of empathy makes one unable to put oneself in the other person's shoes, which predicts prejudice and antidemocratic views.
==Correlation with conservative political views==
Felicia Pratto and her colleagues have found evidence that a high social dominance orientation is strongly correlated with [[conservatism|conservative]] political views, and opposition to programs and policies that aim to promote equality (such as [[affirmative action]], laws advocating [[Civil rights|equal rights]] for [[homosexuals]], women in combat, etc.).<ref name=pratto>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.67.4.741 |title=Social dominance orientation: A personality variable predicting social and political attitudes |year=1994 |last1=Pratto |first1=Felicia |last2=Sidanius |first2=Jim |last3=Stallworth |first3=Lisa M. |last4=Malle |first4=Bertram F. |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=741–63|url=http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:HUL.InstRepos:3207711 }}</ref>
There has been some debate within the psychology community on what the relation is between SDO and racism/sexism. One explanation suggests that opposition to programs that promote equality need not be based on racism or sexism but on a "principled conservatism",<ref name=sidanius96>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.70.3.476 |title=Racism, conservatism, Affirmative Action, and intellectual sophistication: A matter of principled conservatism or group dominance? |year=1996 |last1=Sidanius |first1=Jim |last2=Pratto |first2=Felicia |last3=Bobo |first3=Lawrence |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=70 |issue=3 |pages=476–90|citeseerx=10.1.1.474.1114 }}</ref> that is, a "concern for [[Equality of opportunity|equity]], [[Color blindness (race)|color-blindness]], and genuine conservative values".
Some principled-conservatism theorists have suggested that racism and conservatism are independent, and only very weakly correlated among the highly educated, who truly understand the concepts of conservative values and attitudes. In an effort to examine the relationship between education, SDO, and racism, Sidanius and his colleagues<ref name=sidanius96 /> asked approximately 4,600 Euro-Americans to complete a survey in which they were asked about their political and social attitudes, and their social dominance orientation was assessed. "These findings contradict much of the case for the principled conservatism hypothesis, which maintains that political values that are largely devoid of racism, especially among highly educated people." Contrary to what these theorists would predict, correlations among SDO, political conservatism, and racism were strongest among the most educated, and weakest among the least educated. Sidanius and his colleagues hypothesized<ref name=sidanius96 /> this was because the most educated conservatives tend to be more invested in the hierarchical structure of society and in maintaining the inequality of the [[status quo]] in society in order to safeguard their status.
==Culture== SDO is typically measured as an individual personality construct. However, cultural forms of SDO have been discovered on the macro level of society.<ref name="Fischer 2012">{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1467-9221.2012.00884.x |title=Cultural and Institutional Determinants of Social Dominance Orientation: A Cross-Cultural Meta-Analysis of 27 Societies |year=2012 |last1=Fischer |first1=Ronald |last2=Hanke |first2=Katja |last3=Sibley |first3=Chris G. |journal=Political Psychology |volume=33 |issue=4 |pages=437–67}}</ref> Discrimination, prejudice and stereotyping can occur at various levels of institutions in society, such as transnational corporations, government agencies, schools and criminal justice systems. The basis of this theory of societal level SDO is rooted in [[evolutionary psychology]], which states that humans have an evolved predisposition to express social dominance that is heightened under certain social conditions (such as group status) and is also mediated by factors such as individual personality and temperament. Democratic societies are lower in SDO measures<ref name="Fischer 2012"/> The more that a society encourages citizens to cooperate with others and feel concern for the welfare of others, the lower the SDO in that culture. High levels of national income and empowerment of women are also associated with low national SDO, whereas more traditional societies with lower income, male domination and more closed institutional systems are associated with a higher SDO. Individuals who are socialized within these traditional societies are more likely to internalize gender hierarchies and are less likely to challenge them.
==Biology and sexual differences== The biology of SDO is unknown.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
Plenty of evidence suggests that men tend to score higher on SDO than women, and this is true across different countries, cultures, age-groups, classes, religions and educational levels.<ref name="Sidanius1994" /> Researchers argue for an 'invariance' in the difference between men and women's SDO; suggesting that even if all other factors were to be controlled for, the difference between men and women's SDO would still remain – this however in some cases is disproved.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Inverse gender gap in Germany: Social dominance orientation among men and women|journal = [[International Journal of Psychology]] |date = 2011-02-01|issn = 1464-066X|pages = 33–45|volume = 46|issue = 1|doi = 10.1080/00207594.2010.491121|pmid = 22044131|first = Beate|last = Küpper|first2 = Andreas|last2 = Zick}}</ref>
From an evolutionary and biological perspective SDO facilitates men to be successful in their reproductive strategy through achieving social power and control over other males and becoming desired mating partners for the opposite sex.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Political Psychology of Reproductive Strategies|url = http://pss.sagepub.com/content/11/1/57|journal = Psychological Science|date = 2000-01-01|issn = 0956-7976|pmid = 11228844|pages = 57–62|volume = 11|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/1467-9280.00215|first = Felicia|last = Pratto|first2 = Peter|last2 = Hegarty}}</ref>
Males are observed to be more socially hierarchical, as indicated by speaking time,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1468-2958.2002.tb00814.x |title=Dominance as Expressed and Inferred Through Speaking Time |year=2002 |last1=Mast |first1=Marianne Schmid |journal=Human Communication Research |volume=28 |issue=3 |pages=420–450}}</ref> and yielding to interruptions.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1177/0146167202281003 |title=Female Dominance Hierarchies: Are They Any Different from Males'? |year=2002 |last1=Mast |first1=M. S. |journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin |volume=28 |pages=29–39}}</ref>
Noting that males tend to have higher SDO scores than females, Sidanius and Pratto speculate that SDO may be influenced by hormones that differ between the sexes, namely [[androgen]]s, primarily [[testosterone]]. Male levels of testosterone are much higher than that of females.
Taking a socio-cultural perspective, it is argued that the gap between women and men in SDO is dependent upon [[Norm (social)|societal norms]] prescribing different expectations for [[gender role]]s of men and women.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Gender Gaps in Sociopolitical Attitudes: A Social Psychological Analysis.|journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|pages = 796–816|volume = 87|issue = 6|doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.87.6.796|first = Alice H.|last = Eagly|first2 = Amanda B.|last2 = Diekman|first3 = Mary C.|last3 = Johannesen-Schmidt|first4 = Anne M.|last4 = Koenig|pmid=15598107|year = 2004}}</ref> Men are expected to be dominant and assertive, whereas women are supposed to be submissive and tender.
Differences between male and female attributional cognitive complexity is suggested contribute to the gender gap in SDO.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Gender Differences in Social Dominance Orientation: The Role of Cognitive Complexity|journal = Sex Roles|date = 2010-04-15|issn = 0360-0025|pages = 684–692|volume = 62|issue = 9–10|doi = 10.1007/s11199-010-9775-5|first = Rob|last = Foels|first2 = Landon D.|last2 = Reid}}</ref> Women have been found to be more attributionally complex compared to men; they use more contextual information and evaluate social information more precisely. It is proposed that lower social status prompts higher cognitive complexity in order to compensate for the lack of control in that social situation by processing it more attentively and evaluating it more in depth. The difference in cognitive complexity between high and low status individuals could contribute to the differences between male and female SDO.<ref name=":4" />
==See also== *[[Right wing authoritarianism]] *[[Common ingroup identity]] *[[Demagogy]] *[[Moral Majority]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

revision.text:
In [[Jonathan Swift]]'s novel ''[[Gulliver's Travels]]'', the name '''struldbrugg''' (sometimes spelled '''struldbrug''')[https://books.google.ca/books?id=LWzqWRyWob0C&pg=PA362&lpg=PA362&dq=struldbrug&source=bl&ots=5B2AHnMKZZ&sig=4wx-uFcXRfbEhEDfarRjSCUdF_4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwijuIeCtdjcAhVKuVMKHYgjBScQ6AEwbHoECAoQAQ#v=onepage&q=struldbrug&f=false ''The Living Age''], fifth series volume LVIII (from the beginning, volume CLXXIII) (April/May/June 1887)[https://books.google.ca/books?id=INM_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA387&lpg=PA387&dq=struldbrug&source=bl&ots=Wtj_rOg8Zp&sig=-zdThFt0zOWwqB487OlxtxpjJic&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwijuIeCtdjcAhVKuVMKHYgjBScQ6AEwZXoECBEQAQ#v=onepage&q=struldbrug&f=false The Index ...: A Weekly Paper, Volume 3; Volume 14], by Benjamin Franklin Underwood, 1883[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/comment/outlook-hewitt-grasps-nettle-of-britains-growing-struldbrug-problem-94501.html Outlook: Hewitt grasps nettle of Britain's growing Struldbrug problem], by Jeremy Warner, in ''[[The Independent]]'', published July 3 2003; retrieved August 6 2018[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/2883789/The-Struldbrugs-of-Luggnagg-and-an-age-old-problem-foretold.html The Struldbrugs of Luggnagg and an age-old problem foretold], by Ian Cowie, in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''; published April 24, 2004; retrieved August 6, 2018 is given to those humans in the nation of [[Luggnagg]] who are born seemingly normal, but are in fact [[Immortality|immortal]]. However, although struldbruggs do not ''die'', they do nonetheless continue ''[[aging]]''. Swift's work depicts the evil of immortality without eternal youth. They are easily recognized by a red dot above their left eyebrow. They are normal human beings until they reach the age of thirty, at which time they become dejected. Upon reaching the age of eighty they become legally dead, and suffer from many ailments including the loss of eyesight and the loss of hair. Struldbruggs were forbidden to own property:
As soon as they have completed the term of eighty years, they are looked on as dead in law; their heirs immediately succeed to their estates; only a small pittance is reserved for their support; and the poor ones are maintained at the public charge. After that period, they are held incapable of any employment of trust or profit; they cannot purchase lands, or take leases; neither are they allowed to be witnesses in any cause, either civil or criminal or economic, not even for the decision of meers (metes) and bounds.
Because:
Otherwise, as avarice is the necessary consequence of old age, those immortals would in time become proprietors of the whole nation, and engross the civil power, which, for want of abilities to manage, must end in the ruin of the public.
==Related myths== Chinese [[Taoism]] placed the [[Penglai Mountain|Island of the Immortals]] eastward from China, while Swift places the struldbrugs near Japan. The term ''struldbrug'' has been used in [[science fiction]], most prolifically by [[Larry Niven]]''[[World of Ptavvs]]'', 1966; "the Struldbrugs Club" and [[Robert Silverberg]], to describe [[supercentenarian]]s. ==See also== * [[Brobdingnag]] * [[Lilliput and Blefuscu]] * [[Houyhnhnm]] * [[Yahoo (Gulliver's Travels)]] * [[Tithonus]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Gulliver's Travels}} [[Category:Gulliver's Travels]] [[Category:Immortality in fiction]]

revision.comment: fix cite for extra text into "author="
revision.text:
'''Aleksandr Yuryevich Dolmatov''' ({{lang-ru|Алекса́ндр Ю́рьевич Долма́тов}}; 12 September 1976 – 17 January 2013 [[Rotterdam]]) was a [[Russia]]n [[Russian opposition|opposition]] activist. Dolmatov committed suicide in a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] detention centre. ==Biography== Dolmatov was born on 12 September 1976. In 2004 he took a job at a government-owned defense firm [[Tactical Missiles Corporation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/politics/2012/06/26_a_4643133.shtml|title=«Посадили бы и прессовали по полной программе»|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2018}} ==Oppositional activities== Dolmatov was a member of the unregistered [[National Bolshevik Party]] and the opposition party [[The Other Russia (party)|The Other Russia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/russian/mobile/international/2013/01/130121_dolmatov_mother_letter.shtml|title=BBC Russian - В мире - Мать Долматова написала письмо королеве Нидерландов|website=www.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=25 June 2018}} Beginning in 2010 Dolmatov took part in all actions of [[Strategy-31]], a series of civic protests in [[Moscow]]. Dolmatov was repeatedly detained during Strategy-31 actions. Dolmatov had participated in the so-called [[2011–13 Russian protests|"March of Millions"]], an opposition demonstration on 6 May 2012 which resulted in clashes with police. Dolmatov was detained by police. ==Death== Dolmatov went to the [[Netherlands]] in June 2012, fearing arrest in Russia. He sought political asylum there, but in December the [[Immigration and Naturalisation Service (Netherlands)|Immigration and Naturalisation Service]] turned down his application. Dolmatov was found dead in a Rotterdam deportation centre early on 17 January 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/politics/2013/01/17_a_4930517.shtml|title=Первая смерть в «болотном деле»|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2018}} On 18 April 2013, the [[State Secretary (Netherlands)|State Secretary]] for the [[Ministry of Security and Justice (Netherlands)|Security and Justice]], [[Fred Teeven]], survived a [[vote of no confidence]] on his handling of asylum seekers; the debate was called following a Dutch government agency investigation of the suicide of Dolmatov found that multiple parts of the Dutch immigration system failed him, including medical, legal and state organizations.[http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2013/04/junior_justice_minister_surviv.php Junior justice minister survives debate over Dolmatov suicide], [[DutchNews.nl]] (19 April 2013)
[https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-04-12/world/38482826_1_alexander-dolmatov-political-asylum-rotterdam Dutch investigation divides blame for Russian dissident Dolmatov’s death; gov’t to pay damages], [[The Washington Post]] (12 April 2013) ==Reactions== On 18 January 2013, opposition activists picketed the Dutch Embassy in [[Moscow]][http://drugoros.ru/news/1/3127.html В Москве прошла акция памяти Александра] and [[Saint Petersburg]],[http://drugoros.ru/news/1/3124.html Петербургские другороссы провели акцию памяти Александра Долматова у консульства Нидерландов] [[Russia]] and [[Kiev]],{{nl icon}} [http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2013/01/18/teeven-stelt-onderzoek-in-naar-dood-russische-asielzoeker/ Teeven stelt onderzoek in naar dood Russische asielzoeker 'die onterecht vastzat'], [[NRC Handelsblad]] (18 January 2013)
[http://photo.unian.net/eng/themes/37600/ Picket in memory about the Russian member of the opposition Aleksandr Dolmatov], [[UNIAN]] (18 January 2013) [[Ukraine]] in memory of Aleksandr Dolmatov. Some observers remained convinced that Dolmatov committed suicide under duress after being approached twice by secret police.[http://izvestia.ru/news/543246 Правозащитники требуют от Голландии ответить за гибель Долматова]{{cite web |url= http://www.kp.ru/daily/26017/2939400 |title= Эдуард Лимонов о суициде Александра Долматова: «Сашу допрашивали с пристрастием» |author= Александр КОЦ - Сайт «Комсомольской правды» |date=19 January 2013 |publisher= |accessdate=25 June 2018}} Dolmatov's lawyer Yevgeny Arkhipov criticised the Dutch decision to place him in a deportation centre. [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russia's Foreign Ministry]] said it had demanded the Netherlands investigate Aleksandr Dolmatov's death.{{cite web|url=http://ria.ru/incidents/20130118/918729752.html|title=Москва потребовала от Нидерландов расследовать смерть Долматова|date=18 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=1009239|title=Москва требует скорейшего расследования смерти оппозиционера Долматова|website=vesti.ru|accessdate=25 June 2018}} The Dutch ambassador to Moscow said that Dolmatov's death was not triggered by the refusal to grant him asylum in the Netherlands.{{cite web|url=http://echo.msk.ru/news/992804-echo.html|title=Власти Нидерландов не связывают самоубийство Александра Долматова с отказом в предоставлении ему политического убежища в стране|website=Эхо Москвы|accessdate=25 June 2018}} The Dutch [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Queen Beatrix]] called the suicide of Dolmatov a "great tragedy".{{cite web|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/politics/news/2013/01/25/n_2723953.shtml|title=Королева Нидерландов прокомментировала смерть Долматова: «большая трагедия» и «сложный случай»|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/466108-beatrix-dood-dolmatov-tragedie.html|title=Beatrix: dood Dolmatov tragedie|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2018}}[http://top.rbc.ru/politics/22/01/2013/841648.shtml Королева Нидерландов ответила на обращение матери А.Долматова] ==See also== * [[Murder of Yuriy Chervochkin]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.gazeta.ru/politics/2012/06/26_a_4643133.shtml June 2012 interview with Aleksandr Dolmatov] on [[Gazeta.ru]] {{ru icon}} * [http://www.ivenj.nl/actueel/inspectierapporten/rapport-het-overlijden-van-alexander-dolmatov.aspx?cp=131&cs=64448 Official Dutch Government report into the death of Dolmatov] {{nl icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dolmatov, Aleksandr}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Russian political activists]] [[Category:National Bolshevik Party politicians]] [[Category:Russian human rights activists]] [[Category:Politicians who committed suicide]] [[Category:Suicides by hanging in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Deaths by person]] [[Category:2013 in the Netherlands]] revision.text:
In [[psychology]], '''Transmarginal inhibition''', or TMI, is an organism's response to overwhelming stimuli.
==Research== [[Ivan Pavlov]] enumerated details of TMI on his work of [[Classical conditioning|conditioning]] animals to pain. He found that organisms had different levels of tolerance. He commented "that the most basic inherited difference among people was how soon they reached this shutdown point and that the quick-to-shut-down have a fundamentally different type of nervous system."<ref>Rokhin, L.; Pavlov, I. & Popov, Y. (1963) ''Psychopathology and Psychiatry''. Foreign Languages Publication House: Moscow.</ref>
Patients who have reached this shutdown point often become socially dysfunctional or develop one of several [[personality disorder]]s. Often patients who dissociate during and after the experience, will more easily dissociate or shut down during stressful or painful experiences, and may experience [[post traumatic stress disorder]] for the remainder of their lives.
==Stages==
There are three stages passed through for state of TMI to be reached. #''equivalent phase'': when the response matches the stimuli, which is considered the normal baseline behavior. #''paradoxical phase'': associated with ''quantity reversal'', occurs when small stimuli receive major responses and major stimuli elicit small responses. #''ultra-paradoxical'': the final stage, associated with ''quality reversal'' in which negative stimulation results in positive responses and vice versa.<ref>[http://www.changingminds.org/explanations/behaviors/conditioning/transmarginal_inhibition.htm Transmarginal Inhibition<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Additional research on these phases was done by [[William Sargant]] in his work on [[shell-shock]]ed servicemen.
An organism can progress through these stages by increased stimulation, random negative stimulation, reversing positive and negative stimulation, or physically debilitating the organism.
As observed by Pavlov, tolerance of stimulation varies greatly between individuals. [[Highly sensitive persons]] may be overstimulated by the loud volumes in a movie theater or the background confusion of a large social gathering. Other individuals will find those same stimulations as ideal stimulation levels, or even understimulating.
==Use in mental conditioning== The ''sudden conversion'' methods of mental conditioning rely heavily on TMI. Of the ten elements of control (environment control, physical fatigue, mental fatigue, tension or uncertainty, confession, superstimulation, crisis, euphoria, proselytization, and restimulation), six can be seen as stimulation toward TMI.{{fact|date=September 2008}}
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Stress]] [[Category:Pain]] [[Category:Perception]]

revision.text:
'''Tumor-associated macrophages''' ('''TAMs''') are a class of immune cells present in high numbers in the microenvironment of solid tumors. They are heavily involved in cancer-related inflammation. Macrophages are known to originate from bone marrow-derived blood monocytes (monocyte-derived macrophages) or yolk sac progenitors (tissue-resident macrophages), but the exact origin of TAMs in human tumors remains to be elucidated.<ref name = "Komohara">{{cite journal|last1=Komohara|first1=Yoshihiro|last2=Fujiwara|first2=Yukio|last3=Ohnishi|first3=Koji|last4=Takeya|first4=Motohiro|title=Tumor-associated macrophages: Potential therapeutic targets for anti-cancer therapy|journal=Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews|date=April 2016|volume=99|issue=Pt B|pages=180–185|doi=10.1016/j.addr.2015.11.009|pmid=26621196}}</ref> The composition of monocyte-derived macrophages and tissue-resident macrophages in the tumor microenvironment depends on the tumor type, stage, size, and location, thus it has been proposed that TAM identity and heterogeneity is the outcome of interactions between tumor-derived, tissue-specific, and developmental signals.<ref name="Ostuni">{{cite journal|last1=Ostuni|first1=Renato|last2=Kratochvill|first2=Franz|last3=Murray|first3=Peter J.|last4=Natoli|first4=Gioacchino|title=Macrophages and cancer: from mechanisms to therapeutic implications|journal=Trends in Immunology|date=April 2015|volume=36|issue=4|pages=229–239|doi=10.1016/j.it.2015.02.004|pmid=25770924}}</ref>
==Function== Although there is some debate, most evidence suggests that TAMs have a tumor-promoting phenotype. TAMs affect most aspects of tumor cell biology and drive pathological phenomena including tumor cell proliferation, tumor angiogenesis, invasion and [[metastasis]], immunosuppression, and drug resistance.<ref name="Qian">{{cite journal|last1=Qian|first1=Bin-Zhi|last2=Pollard|first2=Jeffrey W.|title=Macrophage Diversity Enhances Tumor Progression and Metastasis|journal=Cell|date=April 2010|volume=141|issue=1|pages=39–51|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2010.03.014|pmid=20371344|pmc=4994190}}</ref><ref name="Mantovani">{{cite journal|last1=Mantovani|first1=Alberto|last2=Marchesi|first2=Federica|last3=Malesci|first3=Alberto|last4=Laghi|first4=Luigi|last5=Allavena|first5=Paola|title=Tumour-associated macrophages as treatment targets in oncology|journal=Nature Reviews Clinical Oncology|date=24 January 2017|volume=14|issue=7|pages=399–416|doi=10.1038/nrclinonc.2016.217|pmid=28117416|pmc=5480600}}</ref>
===Angiogenesis=== Tumor [[angiogenesis]] is the process by which a tumor forms new blood vessels in order to maintain a supply of nutrients and oxygen and to grow beyond a few millimeters in size. The formation of vasculature also facilitates the escape of malignant cells into blood circulation and the onset of metastasis. One of the primary tumor-promoting mechanisms of TAMs is the secretion of potent pro-angiogenic factors. The most highly expressed and well-characterized angiogenic factor produced by TAMs is [[vascular endothelial growth factor A]] (VEGF-A).<ref name="Riabov">{{cite journal|last1=Riabov|first1=Vladimir|last2=Gudima|first2=Alexandru|last3=Wang|first3=Nan|last4=Mickley|first4=Amanda|last5=Orekhov|first5=Alexander|last6=Kzhyshkowska|first6=Julia|title=Role of tumor associated macrophages in tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis|journal=Frontiers in Physiology|date=5 March 2014|volume=5|pages=75|doi=10.3389/fphys.2014.00075|pmid=24634660|pmc=3942647}}</ref> TAMs accumulate in hypoxic regions of the tumor, which induces the expression of [[hypoxia-inducible factors]] (HIF-1) that regulate VEGF expression. In addition to producing VEGF-A, TAMs have been shown to modulate VEGF-A concentration through [[matrix metalloproteinase]] (MMP)-9 activity<ref name="Bergers">{{cite journal|last1=Bergers|first1=Gabriele|last2=Brekken|first2=Rolf|last3=McMahon|first3=Gerald|last4=Vu|first4=Thiennu H.|last5=Itoh|first5=Takeshi|last6=Tamaki|first6=Kazuhiko|last7=Tanzawa|first7=Kazuhiko|last8=Thorpe|first8=Philip|last9=Itohara|first9=Shigeyoshi|last10=Werb|first10=Zena|last11=Hanahan|first11=Douglas|title=Matrix metalloproteinase-9 triggers the angiogenic switch during carcinogenesis|journal=Nature Cell Biology|date=1 October 2000|volume=2|issue=10|pages=737–744|doi=10.1038/35036374|pmid=11025665|pmc=2852586}}</ref> and by producing [[WNT7B]] that induces endothelial cells to produce VEGF-A.<ref name="Yeo">{{cite journal|last1=Yeo|first1=E.-J.|last2=Cassetta|first2=L.|last3=Qian|first3=B.-Z.|last4=Lewkowich|first4=I.|last5=Li|first5=J.-f.|last6=Stefater|first6=J. A.|last7=Smith|first7=A. N.|last8=Wiechmann|first8=L. S.|last9=Wang|first9=Y.|last10=Pollard|first10=J. W.|last11=Lang|first11=R. A.|title=Myeloid WNT7b Mediates the Angiogenic Switch and Metastasis in Breast Cancer|journal=Cancer Research|date=17 March 2014|volume=74|issue=11|pages=2962–2973|doi=10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-13-2421|pmid=24638982|pmc=4137408}}</ref>
In addition to VEGF-A, TAMs secrete the pro-angiogenic factors [[tumor necrosis factor α]] (TNFα), [[basic fibroblast growth factor]], [[urokinase|urokinase-type plasminogen activator]], [[adrenomedullin]], and [[semaphorin 4D]].<ref name="Riabov" /> Moreover, cytokines produced by TAMs induce tumor cells to produce pro-angiogenic factors, thereby working cooperatively to turn on the angiogenic switch.
A class of TAMs expressing [[Tie2]] have been shown to induce tumor angiogenesis.<ref name="De Palma">{{cite journal|last1=De Palma|first1=Michele|last2=Venneri|first2=Mary Anna|last3=Galli|first3=Rossella|last4=Sergi|first4=Lucia Sergi|last5=Politi|first5=Letterio S.|last6=Sampaolesi|first6=Maurilio|last7=Naldini|first7=Luigi|title=Tie2 identifies a hematopoietic lineage of proangiogenic monocytes required for tumor vessel formation and a mesenchymal population of pericyte progenitors|journal=Cancer Cell|date=September 2005|volume=8|issue=3|pages=211–226|doi=10.1016/j.ccr.2005.08.002|pmid=16169466}}</ref> Tie2<sup>+</sup> TAMs associate with blood vessels through [[ANGPT2|angiopoietin-2]] produced by endothelial cells and activate angiogenesis through paracrine signaling. When angiopoietin-2 is bound, these TAMs upregulate expression of more angiogenic factors, such as [[thymidine phosphorylase]] and [[cathepsin B]]. Angiopoietin-2 also causes Tie2<sup>+</sup> TAMs to express T-cell regulating factors [[interleukin 10|interleukin (IL)-10]] and [[CCL17|chemokine (C-C motif) ligand (CCL) 17]]; these factors limit T-cell proliferation and upregulate expansion of regulatory T cells, allowing tumor cells to evade immune responses.<ref name="Coffelt">{{cite journal|last1=Coffelt|first1=Seth B.|last2=Chen|first2=Yung-Yi|last3=Muthana|first3=Munitta|last4=Welford|first4=Abigail F.|last5=Tal|first5=Andrea O.|last6=Scholz|first6=Alexander|last7=Plate|first7=Karl H.|last8=Reiss|first8=Yvonne|last9=Murdoch|first9=Craig|last10=De Palma|first10=Michele|last11=Lewis|first11=Claire E.|title=Angiopoietin 2 Stimulates TIE2-Expressing Monocytes To Suppress T Cell Activation and To Promote Regulatory T Cell Expansion|journal=The Journal of Immunology|date=1 April 2011|volume=186|issue=7|pages=4183–4190|doi=10.4049/jimmunol.1002802|pmid=21368233}}</ref> Moreover, tumor-produced [[CSF1|colony stimulating factor-1]] (CSF1), which regulates macrophage lineage, increases expression of Tie2 on TAMs, suggesting that CSF1 and Tie2<sup>+</sup> TAMs may play a role in the angiogenic switch.<ref name="Forget">{{cite journal|last1=Forget|first1=Mary A.|last2=Voorhees|first2=Jeffrey L.|last3=Cole|first3=Sara L.|last4=Dakhlallah|first4=Duaa|last5=Patterson|first5=Ivory L.|last6=Gross|first6=Amy C.|last7=Moldovan|first7=Leni|last8=Mo|first8=Xiaokui|last9=Evans|first9=Randall|last10=Marsh|first10=Clay B.|last11=Eubank|first11=Tim D.|last12=Valledor|first12=Annabel|title=Macrophage Colony-Stimulating Factor Augments Tie2-Expressing Monocyte Differentiation, Angiogenic Function, and Recruitment in a Mouse Model of Breast Cancer|journal=PLoS ONE|date=3 June 2014|volume=9|issue=6|pages=e98623|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0098623|pmid=24892425|pmc=4043882}}</ref>
Tumor [[lymphangiogenesis]] is closely related to tumor angiogenesis, and there is substantial evidence that factors produced by TAMs, especially those of the VEGF family and their receptor tyrosine kinases, are responsible for this link.<ref name="Gomes">{{cite journal|last1=Gomes|first1=Fausto Gueths|last2=Nedel|first2=Fernanda|last3=Alves|first3=Alessandro Menna|last4=Nör|first4=Jacques Eduardo|last5=Tarquinio|first5=Sandra Beatriz Chaves|title=Tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis: Tumor/endothelial crosstalk and cellular/microenvironmental signaling mechanisms|journal=Life Sciences|date=February 2013|volume=92|issue=2|pages=101–107|doi=10.1016/j.lfs.2012.10.008|pmid=23178150|pmc=3740377}}</ref><ref name="Scavelli">{{cite journal|last1=Scavelli|first1=C|last2=Vacca|first2=A|last3=Di Pietro|first3=G|last4=Dammacco|first4=F|last5=Ribatti|first5=D|title=Crosstalk between angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis in tumor progression|journal=Leukemia|date=1 April 2004|volume=18|issue=6|pages=1054–1058|doi=10.1038/sj.leu.2403355|pmid=15057248}}</ref>
===Immune suppression=== One of the major functions of TAMs is suppressing the T-cell mediated anti-tumor immune response. Gene expression analysis of mouse models of breast cancer and fibrosarcoma shows that TAMs have immunosuppressive transcriptional profiles and express factors including IL-10 and [[transforming growth factor β]] (TGFβ).<ref name="Biswas">{{cite journal|last1=Biswas|first1=S. K.|title=A distinct and unique transcriptional program expressed by tumor-associated macrophages (defective NF- B and enhanced IRF-3/STAT1 activation)|journal=Blood|date=1 March 2006|volume=107|issue=5|pages=2112–2122|doi=10.1182/blood-2005-01-0428|pmid=16269622}}</ref><ref name="Ojalvo">{{cite journal|last1=Ojalvo|first1=Laureen S.|last2=King|first2=William|last3=Cox|first3=Dianne|last4=Pollard|first4=Jeffrey W.|title=High-Density Gene Expression Analysis of Tumor-Associated Macrophages from Mouse Mammary Tumors|journal=The American Journal of Pathology|date=March 2009|volume=174|issue=3|pages=1048–1064|doi=10.2353/ajpath.2009.080676|pmid=19218341|pmc=2665764}}</ref> In humans, TAMs have been shown to directly suppress T cell function through surface presentation of [[PD-L1|programmed death-ligand 1]] (PD-L1) in hepatocellular carcinoma<ref name="Kuang">{{cite journal|last1=Kuang|first1=Dong-Ming|last2=Zhao|first2=Qiyi|last3=Peng|first3=Chen|last4=Xu|first4=Jing|last5=Zhang|first5=Jing-Ping|last6=Wu|first6=Changyou|last7=Zheng|first7=Limin|title=Activated monocytes in peritumoral stroma of hepatocellular carcinoma foster immune privilege and disease progression through PD-L1|journal=The Journal of Experimental Medicine|date=8 June 2009|volume=206|issue=6|pages=1327–1337|doi=10.1084/jem.20082173|pmid=19451266|pmc=2715058}}</ref> and B7-homologs in ovarian carcinoma,<ref name="Kryczek">{{cite journal|last1=Kryczek|first1=Ilona|last2=Zou|first2=Linhua|last3=Rodriguez|first3=Paulo|last4=Zhu|first4=Gefeng|last5=Wei|first5=Shuang|last6=Mottram|first6=Peter|last7=Brumlik|first7=Michael|last8=Cheng|first8=Pui|last9=Curiel|first9=Tyler|last10=Myers|first10=Leann|last11=Lackner|first11=Andrew|last12=Alvarez|first12=Xavier|last13=Ochoa|first13=Augusto|last14=Chen|first14=Lieping|last15=Zou|first15=Weiping|title=B7-H4 expression identifies a novel suppressive macrophage population in human ovarian carcinoma|journal=The Journal of Experimental Medicine|date=17 April 2006|volume=203|issue=4|pages=871–881|doi=10.1084/jem.20050930|pmid=16606666|pmc=2118300}}</ref> which activate [[programmed cell death protein 1]] (PD-1) and [[CTLA-4|cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen 4]] (CTLA-4), respectively, on T cells. Inhibitory signals to PD-1 and CTLA-4 are immune checkpoints, and binding of these inhibitory receptors by their ligands prevents T cell receptor signaling, inhibits T cells cytotoxic function, and promotes T cell apoptosis.<ref name="Ostuni" /><ref name="Noy">{{cite journal|last1=Noy|first1=Roy|last2=Pollard|first2=Jeffrey W.|title=Tumor-Associated Macrophages: From Mechanisms to Therapy|journal=Immunity|date=July 2014|volume=41|issue=1|pages=49–61|doi=10.1016/j.immuni.2014.06.010|pmid=25035953|pmc=4137410}}</ref> HIF-1α also induces TAMs to suppress T cell function through arginase-1, but the mechanism by which this occurs is not yet fully understood.<ref name="Doedens">{{cite journal|last1=Doedens|first1=A. L.|last2=Stockmann|first2=C.|last3=Rubinstein|first3=M. P.|last4=Liao|first4=D.|last5=Zhang|first5=N.|last6=DeNardo|first6=D. G.|last7=Coussens|first7=L. M.|last8=Karin|first8=M.|last9=Goldrath|first9=A. W.|last10=Johnson|first10=R. S.|title=Macrophage Expression of Hypoxia-Inducible Factor-1 Suppresses T-Cell Function and Promotes Tumor Progression|journal=Cancer Research|date=14 September 2010|volume=70|issue=19|pages=7465–7475|doi=10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-10-1439|pmid=20841473|pmc=2948598}}</ref>
==Subtypes== TAMs have historically been described as falling into two categories: M1 and M2. M1 refers to macrophages that undergo “classical” activation by [[Interferon gamma|interferon-γ]] (IFNγ) with either lipopolysaccharide (LPS) or TNF, whereas M2 refers to macrophages that undergo “alternative” activation by [[Interleukin 4|IL-4]].<ref name="Martinez">{{cite journal|last1=Martinez|first1=Fernando O.|last2=Gordon|first2=Siamon|title=The M1 and M2 paradigm of macrophage activation: time for reassessment|journal=F1000Prime Reports|date=3 March 2014|volume=6|pages=13|doi=10.12703/P6-13|pmid=24669294|pmc=3944738}}</ref> M1 macrophages are seen to have a pro-inflammatory and cytotoxic (anti-tumoral) function; M2 macrophages are anti-inflammatory (pro-tumoral) and promote wound healing. However, use of the [[Macrophage polarization|M1/M2 polarization]] paradigm has led to confusing terminology since M1/M2 are used to describe mature macrophages, but the activation process is complex and involves many related cells in the macrophage family. Moreover, with recent evidence that macrophage populations are tissue- and tumor-specific,<ref name="Ostuni" /> it has been proposed that classifying macrophages, including TAMs, as being in one of two distinct stable subsets is insufficient.<ref name="Martinez" /> Rather, TAMs should be viewed as existing on a spectrum. More comprehensive classification systems that account for the dynamic nature of macrophages have been proposed,<ref name="Ostuni" /> but have not been adopted by the immunological research community.
==Clinical significance== In many tumor types TAM infiltration level has been shown to be of significant [[prognosis|prognostic]] value. TAMs have been linked to poor prognosis in [[breast cancer]], [[ovarian cancer]], types of [[glioma]] and [[lymphoma]]; better prognosis in [[colon cancer|colon]] and [[stomach cancer|stomach]] cancers and both poor and better prognoses in [[lung cancer|lung]] and [[prostate cancer|prostate]] cancers.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Allavena | first1 = P. | last2 = Sica | first2 = A. | last3 = Solinas | first3 = G. | last4 = Porta | first4 = C. | last5 = Mantovani | first5 = A. | title = The inflammatory micro-environment in tumor progression: The role of tumor-associated macrophages | doi = 10.1016/j.critrevonc.2007.07.004 | journal = Critical Reviews in Oncology/Hematology | volume = 66 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–9 | year = 2008 | pmid = 17913510| pmc = }}</ref>
Clinically, in 128 patients with breast cancer it was found that patients with more M2 tumor-associated macrophages had higher-grade tumors, greater microvessel density, and worse overall survival. Patients with more M1 tumor-associated macrophages displayed the opposite effect.<ref>De la Cruz-Merino L, Barco-Sanchez A, Henao Carrasco F, et al.: New insights into the role of the immune microenvironment in breast carcinoma. Dev Immunol 2013; 2013: 785317.</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Carly Bess|last2=Yeh|first2=Elizabeth S|last3=Soloff|first3=Adam C|date=2016-01-20|title=Tumor-associated macrophages: unwitting accomplices in breast cancer malignancy|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/npjbcancer201525|journal=Npj Breast Cancer|language=en|volume=2|issue=1|doi=10.1038/npjbcancer.2015.25|pmid=26998515|pmc=4794275|issn=2374-4677}}</ref>
==As a drug target== CSF1R inhibitors have been developed as a potential route to reduce the presence of TAMs in the tumor microenvironment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pyonteck|first1=Stephanie M.|last2=Akkari|first2=Leila|last3=Schuhmacher|first3=Alberto J.|last4=Bowman|first4=Robert L.|last5=Sevenich|first5=Lisa|last6=Quail|first6=Daniela F.|last7=Olson|first7=Oakley C.|last8=Quick|first8=Marsha L.|last9=Huse|first9=Jason T.|last10=Teijeiro|first10=Virginia|last11=Setty|first11=Manu|last12=Leslie|first12=Christina S.|last13=Oei|first13=Yoko|last14=Pedraza|first14=Alicia|last15=Zhang|first15=Jianan|last16=Brennan|first16=Cameron W.|last17=Sutton|first17=James C.|last18=Holland|first18=Eric C.|last19=Daniel|first19=Dylan|last20=Joyce|first20=Johanna A.|title=CSF-1R inhibition alters macrophage polarization and blocks glioma progression|journal=Nature Medicine|date=October 2013|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1264–1272|doi=10.1038/nm.3337|pmid=24056773|pmc=3840724|issn=1078-8956}}</ref> As of 2017, CSF1R inhibitors that are currently in early stage clinical trials include [[Pexidartinib]], [[PLX7486]], ARRY-382, JNJ-40346527, BLZ945, [[Emactuzumab]], AMG820, IMC-CS4, MCS110, and Cabiralizumab.<ref name=Cannarile2017>{{cite journal |title=Colony-stimulating factor 1 receptor (CSF1R) inhibitors in cancer therapy |author=Cannarile et al. |year=2017 |journal=Journal for ImmunoTherapy of Cancer |volume = 5|issue=1 |pages=53 |doi=10.1186/s40425-017-0257-y |pmid=28716061 |pmc=5514481 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1200/JCO.2017.35.15_suppl.11078|title = A phase I/II dose escalation and expansion study of cabiralizumab (cabira; FPA-008), an anti-CSF1R antibody, in tenosynovial giant cell tumor (TGCT, diffuse pigmented villonodular synovitis D-PVNS)| journal=Journal of Clinical Oncology| volume=35| issue=15_suppl| pages=11078|year = 2017|last1 = Sankhala|first1 = Kamalesh Kumar| last2=Blay| first2=Jean-Yves| last3=Ganjoo| first3=Kristen N.| last4=Italiano| first4=Antoine| last5=Hassan| first5=Andrew Bassim| last6=Kim| first6=Tae Min| last7=Ravi| first7=Vinod| last8=Cassier| first8=Philippe Alexandre| last9=Rutkowski| first9=Piotr| last10=Sankar| first10=Neil| last11=Qazi| first11=Ibrahim| last12=Sikorski| first12=Robert S.| last13=Collins| first13=Helen| last14=Zhang| first14=Charlie| last15=Shocron| first15=Ellyn| last16=Gelderblom| first16=Hans}}</ref><ref>[https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03158272 A Study to of Cabiralzumab Given by Itself or With Nivolumab in Advanced Cancer or Cancer That Has Spread]</ref><ref>[http://www.onclive.com/web-exclusives/novel-combination-shows-promising-responses-in-pancreatic-cancer ''Novel Combination Shows Promising Responses in Pancreatic Cancer'' Nov 2017]</ref> CSF1R inhibitors such as PLX3397 have also been shown to alter the distribution of TAMs throughout the tumor and promote enrichment of the classically activated M1-like phenotype.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cuccarese|first=Michael F.|last2=Dubach|first2=J. Matthew|last3=Pfirschke|first3=Christina|last4=Engblom|first4=Camilla|last5=Garris|first5=Christopher|last6=Miller|first6=Miles A.|last7=Pittet|first7=Mikael J.|last8=Weissleder|first8=Ralph|date=2017-02-08|title=Heterogeneity of macrophage infiltration and therapeutic response in lung carcinoma revealed by 3D organ imaging|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms14293|journal=Nature Communications|language=En|volume=8|pages=14293|doi=10.1038/ncomms14293|pmid=28176769|pmc=5309815|issn=2041-1723}}</ref><ref name="Rodell">{{Cite journal|last=Rodell|first=Christopher B.|last2=Arlauckas|first2=Sean P.|last3=Cuccarese|first3=Michael F.|last4=Garris|first4=Christopher S.|last5=Li|first5=Ran|last6=Ahmed|first6=Maaz S.|last7=Kohler|first7=Rainer H.|last8=Pittet|first8=Mikael J.|last9=Weissleder|first9=Ralph|date=2018-05-21|title=TLR7/8-agonist-loaded nanoparticles promote the polarization of tumour-associated macrophages to enhance cancer immunotherapy|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41551-018-0236-8|journal=Nature Biomedical Engineering|volume=2|issue=8|pages=578–588|language=En|doi=10.1038/s41551-018-0236-8|issn=2157-846X}}</ref>
Other approaches to enhance tumor response to chemotherapies that have been tested in preclinical models include blocking macrophage recruitment to the tumor site, re-polarizing TAMs, and promoting TAM activation.<ref name="Ruffell">{{cite journal|last1=Ruffell|first1=Brian|last2=Coussens|first2=Lisa M.|title=Macrophages and Therapeutic Resistance in Cancer|journal=Cancer Cell|date=April 2015|volume=27|issue=4|pages=462–472|doi=10.1016/j.ccell.2015.02.015|pmid=25858805|pmc=4400235}}</ref> Remaining challenges in targeting TAMs include determining whether to target depletion or repolarization in combination therapies, and for which tumor types and at what tumor stage TAM-targeted therapy is effective.<ref name="Ruffell" /> Re-polarization of TAMs from a M2 to M1 phenotype by drug treatments has shown the ability to control tumor growth,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guerriero|first=Jennifer L.|last2=Sotayo|first2=Alaba|last3=Ponichtera|first3=Holly E.|last4=Castrillon|first4=Jessica A.|last5=Pourzia|first5=Alexandra L.|last6=Schad|first6=Sara|last7=Johnson|first7=Shawn F.|last8=Carrasco|first8=Ruben D.|last9=Lazo|first9=Suzan|date=March 2017|title=Class IIa HDAC inhibition reduces breast tumours and metastases through anti-tumour macrophages|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature21409|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=543|issue=7645|pages=428–432|doi=10.1038/nature21409|pmid=28273064|issn=0028-0836}}</ref> including in combination with [[checkpoint inhibitor therapy]].<ref name="Rodell"/>
==See also== * [[Tumor microenvironment]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
